text: Bottle from Discount. Looks like 2 years old at this point. Pours a pitch black with a bit of rising carbonation. Dark espresso, roasted cacao and deep prune notes on the nose. Good carbonation, slightly oily on the palate. A little blueberry tartness, more coffee and cacao on the palate. Lingering roasty bitter finish. For 2 years old this still has some nice qualities.

0.355l bottle @ Hotel Room. Quite a deep and dark looking one this. Not too far off being black actually and a nice medium sized quite lacing beige head. Roasted and dark nose. Something that reminds me of vanilla and wood, theres definitely rye bread here. Dark bitter chocolate and come coco powder also. Smells really nice and deep. Really delicious to drink also. Its thick and oily in the mouth and soft prickling on the bubbles. Dark roasted at first. Theres coffee and burnt bread. Kinda mineralish after a while but lots of flavor going on here. Chocolate wrapper in the finish. Highly enjoyed. 10.06.2015

Pours a nice deep golden blackcolor. Aromas of rich dark malts, chocolate, fruit, and a hint of smoke. Flavor is rich with a lot of flavors to be found, chocolate, dark fruit, smoke, coffee, and I swear a hint of licorice.

Opaque black brown, ample tan head, fairly fine. Light roast coffee and chocolate notes, transitioning into resin and some unripe berries. Light bitterness with an underlying sweetness. Medium body, a bit chewy, some light acidity, not much carbonation. Longer finish. Excellent.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is heavy bitter and moderate sweet with roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel and citrics, medium to heavy bodied, smooth, flavor is heavy bitter and moderate sweet, very good black ipa.
From notes (August 2015). Dark, rich, spicy, and hoppy. Its complex and really enjoyable -- it reminded me a lot of Firestone Walkers Wookie Jack.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a glass. Black with small off-white head. Aroma is strong herbal/pine hops, medium body, medium/low carbonation, and pretty good small bubble lacing. Taste is herbal hops, pine hops, some rye, and bitter finish. This is more black IPA than rye for me and this good for what it is, but is not for me.
Bottle to a pint. Pours black with tan head. Beautiful hop aroma with citrus and pine. Flavor balanced with sweet toffee malt... Delicious!!!

Black pour from bottle..not the freshest bottle so might impact things..small tan mocha head..nose is toasted nuts,black licorice, anise, rye grain..taste follows suit..interesting..comes across as a mix between a porter and black ipa.pretty smooth nice flavor..some spice from the rye on the end with a solid lingering finish that has that chocolate presence for sure..would be great with chocolate sweets..

Medium, slightly bitter aroma of licorice, coffee and sweeter dark berries. Pitch black color with medium, creamy, light beige head. Medium/strong aroma of roasted rye malts, coffee, and hint of licorice. Medium balanced with wide/medium taste spectrum and long roasted aftertaste. Medium body with medium/low carbonation. Overall, very tasty with a plus from using rye, thought lacks a bit of body.

12 oz bottle @ home. Didnt notice it when I bought it but it was already a year old... Black color. Big rocky beige head, with some lace. Aromas: resin, roast, drop/laurel/bay leaves, light sweet. Retronasal its resin, laurel/bay leaves, drop. Flavor is moderate bitter, droppy, light sweet, with light acidity on the back of the tongue. Medium bodied. Long ashy finish. Still pretty good, but need to score a fresh bottle sometime.

Bottle, pours a black body with a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate, molasses, and rye. Taste is similar, although the rye is more pronounced. The hops definitely show up near the back of the palate with a very dry finish.

12oz bottle from NEWS. Was 1 per person on the shelf. Didnt look at the date... Bad purchasing decision. Bottle date 12/06/14. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, hamster cage. Flavor isnt too bad... Burnt caramel, some rye spice, pine bitter in the finish. Will find a fresh bottle and re-rate.

12 oz bottle. Pours very dark brown and nearly black in color and topped by a nice layer of khaki colored foam that shows good retention and slowly fades to a thin film. The aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, dark rye malts, earthy roast, toffee, spicy rye, hints of smoke, and pine hop bitterness on the back end. The flavor follows with the dark chocolate, dark rye malts, and earthy roast up front to go with the toffee, spicy rye, burnt wood, and smoke. Pine and citrus hops add ample bitterness on the back end and keeps things balanced. Medium bodied and smooth on the mouthfeel with ample carbonation that leads to a bitter, roasted chocolate finish. Similar to a black IPA with the added rye and a wide range of flavors. Interesting and really good.

Pours a very dark brown with a tan head. A clean lightly citrus nose with a sharper dark roast malt note underneath. Smooth mouthfeel with some bite on the rear of the palate. Ample bitterness at the finish. Dark roast malt competes with an equally hoppy profile.

Deep brown pour with tan head and lace. Aroma is sweet chocolate and rye. Flavor is semi sweet chocolate start with a coffee finish and a good bitter finish. Medium body with good carbonation. Rye comes through as well. solid

12-oz. bottle. The nose is highlighted by dank, musty hops and a touch of charred bark and sweet molasses; theres also a semi-sharp singed plastic aroma in the background. The beer pours opaque black topped by smooth, long-lasting parchment-hued foam. The taste is roast-heavy before a sweet-n-spicy grain tone takes hold. A lightly charred wooden note and hints of bitter chocolate and a whisper of overripe melon and almond come into play late. A crisp, dry finish. Not bad at all; similar to a toned-down black IPA without the assertive hop characteristic.

Pours super dark brown with a medium khaki head. Head retention is poor. AROMA: roasted dark malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel, wood char, smoke, rye spice, herbs, herbal hops, nuts, toffee, molasses, spices, peppercorn, light citrus and dark stone fruit. TASTE: dark roasted malt, rye spice, hop spice, pine bitterness, coffee, chocolate, nuts, caramel, earthy, alcohol, herbs, smoke, wood char, peppercorn, light citrus, spices, toffee, molasses, dark stone fruit and burned brown sugar. AFTER TASTE: dark malt, rye/hop spice, molasses and pine bitterness with an oily smooth, slightly watery finish.

Pours a dark mahogany, indigo color with a small, light tan head that leaves spotty lacing on the glass. Aroma is of chocolate and roasted malts, dough, rye and citrus hops. Heavy body. Flavor is of chocolate, roast, wheat, smoke, dry rye, and finishing with a bitter hoppyness.. Citrus and rye finish.

Probada en Top Hops, Lower East Side, New York. IPA oscura, casi negra, con un fuerte sabor a chocolate. Esta ok.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black. Sweet chocolatey.Dry toasty with herbal earthy slight berry toasty with sweet breadyness planty hops. same in taste. Pretty herbal with lots of berry chocolateness.bready light roast. Hoppy linger. The bitter cleans up the sweet side well but neither is too much. Nice balance
Smelled of chocolaty coffeish goodness. Good flavor. Tastes like stout. Might be somewhat hippy. Had 4 pack from Holmes.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a medium grey head. A big sweet chocolate nose, rye and citrus. The flavor is sweet toasted malt, chocolate, toffee, citrus. Dark roast. Good. Spicy.

New Beer Distributors, NYC bottle: Pours Black with a creamy, tan head. Aroma is rye, roasted malt, piny hops, chocolate, and nuts. Taste is much the same. Not too bitter, but enough to give plenty hops. The rye comes across very well and very clean. Really superbly done. So many brewers just bullshit rye into beer, but here it was done with thought and consideration. Excellent balance. I expected this to be good, but I did not expect to like it this much.

Poured from bottle, a deep chocolate with medium head. Smells like a black IPA. Tastes like chocolate coffee. Mouth feel is thick oil but yet bright. Don't care for the finish at all. In fact, it's the finish that ruins an otherwise enjoyable brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

black with ruby red highlights; roasted malt, rye malt, and floral hop aroma; roasted malt base with lots of coffee notes and lots of hops; a really bitter beer; dry, rye malt character; dry, bitter ryemalt finish
Aroma adocicado com leve toque de torrefação. Coloração escura com espuma persistente. Cerveja leve, com dulçor suave e leve toque alcoólico. Retrogosto persistente de torrefação.
Bottle. Big and bold. The smell is rye, hops, malt, roast, and good. The taste is the the same, pretty nice. Dark, brown in color, tan head. Good beer.
12 oz bottle. Black with an average sized beige head. Aroma is of roasted malt, pine, herbal, and rye. Taste is of pine, light resin, coffee, roasted malts, spicy rye.

(Bottle, 0.355 l, at laitis, 20150613, thanks) The beer poured clear and almost black. Its head was small and lightly brown. Aroma had burnt malts and sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were burnt malts, sweetness, dark bread, pine and bitterness. Aftertaste was roasty and bitter. Nice roasty brew.

Draft. Clearish nearly-black brown with a soft sandy head. Pine, peanut skins, toasted wheat, tree bark and sharp rye swirl in the aroma. The clarity of these notes is lost in the flavor, where things are more muddled and subdued. Malt presence is sweeter here, the rye and torched barley mixing with a little caramel. Pine -- wet, kind of musty -- comprises the hop character. A nice little black IPA with a pronounced rye flavor.
Pour is really black...nice head....no lacing...finish really lingers...ok not great....(#535).....

Bottle. Pours a deep black with a large tan head. Roast and cocoa, chocolate, spicy hops. Medium bodied, big chocolate, cocoa, roast, hops. Long spiciness, roast and cocoa. Chocolate, cocoa, roast and slow grapefruit. Easy drinking.

350ml bottle - thanks VastActiv!
Lovely rich roasty toasty aroma. Sweet chocolate later as it warms a little. Nice roasty body too, dryer than the aroma hinted. Nice balance. Rye is subtle. Burntness there, but no harshness. Well attentuated. Finish stays with the dark roast. Whilst this is lovely, and there is some ryish aspects there, I could do with even more rye (I love rye). Yup, do like this.
Bottle: Dark brown with a tan head. Rye aroma with formaldehyde with a strong bitter flavor. Always well done by Founders.

Pours a very dark and bubbly reddish-brown with an average size off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, chocolate, yeast and light hops-- smells great! Taste is malty with some smoke and chocolate and a long bitter finish. Medium bodied.

355ml bottle @Laitis, thanks. Clear dark copper color. Small size, beige head, disappears. Sweet, roasted malts, toffee, chocolate in aroma. Nice roughly roasted rye, toffee, grainy in taste. Rye-like bitterness. Hit the rye button almost perfectly. Hard grain to deal with and please me so well done! Nice brew!
Aroma and flavor of spicy rye, roasted malt and somewhat nutty. Very dark and a medium weight with a dry finish. Good but there are better rye ales.

35,5 cl bottle @ home, BBE 17.12.2014
Aroma has artifical chocolate tones, sweet malty tones and hints of coffee. Flavour has nettles, artifical chocolate, grainy tones and hayish malt. Somewhat watery and a bit disappointing.
Bottle 0.355l at Laitis, Helsinki. Colour is dark brown with very small head. Aromas and flavours: Chocolate, grain, hops and roasted malts. Very nice hops!

330ml bottle
Pours dark brown with a small light brown head.
Aroma of roasty malts, rye, hints of dark chocolate, leather, grassy hops, pine and syrup.
Taste is sweet, roasty and bitter with some rye, syrup, pine and grass.
Finish is grassy, roasty and hoppy with some licorice, rye, dry bitterness. Pretty good.

Aroma: toast, rye, chocolate, toffee
Appearance: clear black, brown head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, rye, toffee, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, 

Tasty
Great aroma with tobacco coffee leather smoke. Flavors similar. Very easy drinking. Would call the style stout tho.

Location: 12 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 6/10/15


Aroma: It has an aroma of sweet, roasted malts and toasted pumpernickel rye bread

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a foamy light brown head and medium lace

Flavor: The flavor is more bread and roast, less sweet than the nose, with a strong bitterness as well

Palate: The body is medium-plus, with a smooth, creamy feel, and a medium dry finish

Overall Impression: 
Im surprised Ive never rated this one before. This is a very nice beer. The rye, malty, and bitter flavors all work nicely together.  It has a rather nice feel as well.  Theres a lot to like here.

Pours dark brown with a beige head that dissipates fast. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, citrus and coffee. 
Taste is a little sweet with hints of dark cholate/coffee and a dry bitter hoppy aftertaste. The roasted and hoppy flavors are off balance. Each flavor wrestles with your tongue to come out on top.

Bottle 355ml @ Hotel Room, Four Points by Sheraton, Boston, MA
Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, citrus and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and medium bitter with a long roasted, chocolate, coffee, citrus and caramel, Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. A clear-looking dark brown beer topped by a dense, finger-thick beige head. The aroma is mostly on the roasted side, but theres a nice piney hoppyness too.Chocolate, some coffee and soy sauce chimes in. Its dry and full-bodied, with a nice carbonation level. Roasted malts, some faint burnt notes, coffee, chocolate and a little salty hint in the flavor. Lasting finish with roasted malts and a good dash of bitterness. Quite nice, but I find it hard to recognize the rye. Would have hope for some more of that. 150607

12oz bottle. No code date. Appearance: Jet black and opaque, with a thick creamy tan head. 
Aroma: Roasted coffee, toffee, hint of caramel. Also some resinouse hop notes. 
Taste: Sweet roasted malt and toffee dominate, a slight peppery rye bite, and strong hop bitterness with hints of resin and pine. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body with light carbonation. 
Finish: Roast lingers long past swallow, along with some bitterness. 
Overall: Drinks like a Black IPA. Aggressive hopping is evident in the aroma and taste, but to me the balance of roast against the hops isnt as balanced as Id like.

Appearance: basically looks like a stout--near black with half a finger of creamy beige head.  Aroma: toasted brown bread, molasses, dark chocolate, toffee, and tobacco.  Taste: charred rye bread, dark chocolate, caraway, toffee, a hint of leather, and some earthy and resinous hops. Finish: the hops and roasty notes keep things dry and bracing, with a little lingering chocolate. Notes: Wow this was good. Wouldnt call it a black IPA, cant call it a stout. Specialty grains as good as anything. Bottle from Total Wine & More in Fairfax, Virginia (Pickett Center).
Bottle. Clear, black with a small tan head. Aroma is nutty, hoppy and toasted grains. Taste is hints of toffee, nutty undertones and a dry hoppy finish.
Dark Brown with sweet spicy roAsty aroma; Flava is complex roasty sweet hint of berry malty and touch of hops and cigar tobacco; feels medium slight fizz; finishes tangy roasty mildly dry

I love rye, Founders dark beers, and black IPAs. This one was cheating. Poured from a bottle into a tulip. Pours pitch black with a nice tan head. Aroma of rye spice, roasted malt, and a touch of chocolate. Flavor is more of the same with a nice rye presences, a bit of sweetness from the malt, and a good hop bite to balance it out. Medium body, nice carbonation. This is a really solid beer.
real smokey aroma. Taste is velvety milk chocolate, toasted rye and barley, and a little smoke. Some bitter hops in the after taste. A very layered and balanced good beer.

Keg at the Thirsty Monk, Asheville, 17/02/15.
Off black with a decent light tan covering.
Nose is charr, light roast, dark malt, dates, cocoa rub.
Taste comprises spice, chocolate malt, toffee, brown bread, charr.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Ok.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Tap at pies and pints. Pour is black and thick. Head is tan and lingers. Nose is cocoa and coffee and awesome. Thick mouthfeel and smoky notes hiding the rye grain. A bit of sweet balance from the cocoa too without being overpowering.
Deep black but not imperial. Light enough to get the great rye and bitter taste. Tap.

355ml bottle from Whole Foods - Tribeca, New York. Thanks Jesse!


Black colour with a beige head. Hoppy, roasty, malty, some coffee. Nice palate and good drinkability.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Opaque black color, frothy tan head, stripes of lace. Taste is rich roasted toffee malt that contains rye that moves through the palate, becoming a little sweeter with the addition of chocolate, not needing additional bittering to sustain balance. A big, solid brew that leans toward bitter rye.
Bottle pours black with a tan top that fizzles away fast. Nose of rye, chocolate and smoke. Taste is rye, toast and a hint of bitter chocolate.
Dark body, minimal head almost nonexistent. Aroma of black smoky malts, chocolate, and hops. Rye is restrained but most notable in the taste. Pretty good effort, what I come to expect from Founders.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma toasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, & some rye; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, rye, hops, and dark chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Decent.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2015 12 oz pour from 50ish-degree bottle into Spiegelau IPA glass. Pours a huge and fluffy head. Tan-to-brown and long lasting. Beautiful. Black as night and opaque. Nose is rich caramel, brown sugar, mild fruit, and mild wood. Full bodied and fairly creamy. Taste has a good amount going on. Nuts, woody, maybe pine, a bit of caramel sweetness, maybe a tiny bit of fruit, and a little coffee bitterness. Aftertaste has some espresso tartness. Neat overall beer. Very smooth and great flavors.

Bottle from Hannaford Exeter NH. Aroma is resin, herbs, cereal, bread, dough. Appearance is thick, creamy beige head with decent retention and fluffy lacing. Color is deep, dark reddish-brown, virtually black. Taste is roasted bitterness balanced with sweet. Palate is decadent, thick, creamy texture, medium to full bodied with enough carbonation to give it backbone but is restrained and doesnt call attention to itself. Finish is pleasantly long and mildly bitter. Overall, this beer is a delight to all senses and is satisfying in every way.
Pours cola brown color with a creamy off-white head with aroma of coffee, chocolate, and grain. Espresso flavor with chocolate, nut, and toffee. Excellent lacing and tasty beer.

12 oz bottle. Tasted on 4/28/15. Bottle from Moore Liquor. Taste was similar to a hoppy light stout. Nice roasty & slightly nutty with a good hop to balance it out.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very dark pour. A dusty, espresso nose. Lots of roast malt flavor, a slightly burned edge. Medium bitter finish. Tasty.
Poured from tap a reddy black with tan head and lace. Aroma of chocolate, espresso and roasted malts. Taste of chocolate, coffee, fig, with a hoppy bitterness. Creamy.

330 ml bottle. Pours a ruby reddish black with a short lived white head. Aroma is chocolate, burnt, black licorice. Flavor is spicy, licorice, chocolate, dark fruit. Lingering dark chocolate, dark berries and ash. Medium body, average carbonation.
Bottle. Pours near black. Creamy tan head. Mild spicy aroma. Flavor has some spice, but more coffee and some chocolate. Some bitter, but drinks more like a stout. Very nice
Pours dark with ruby edges, off white head that reduces to a lacing ring. Mild rye nose. Taste is chocolate creams idle with a mild dry finish.

Really nice! Pours black with lots of tan frothy head and medium lacing. Nose is fruity and lots of espresso. Flavours of espresso, some nuts, dark fruit, lots of grassy bitterness. Taste med/big bitter med sweet. Full body lively carbonation. Lasting bitterness.

On tap. Served and black color with a small head and some lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, grain and bit of toffee. taste of grain, roasted malt, and nuts. Nice bitterness and a dry finish. Medium body, smooth and nicely balanced. Enjoyable beer.

Pours black with a mottled tan head. Some lacing. Nose is malty; notes of coffee and molasses. Taste is surprisingly bitter and hoppy after the nose. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Very nice brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours pitch black, with a hint of red at the edges when held to the light, a and half-inch of very fine tan/brown foam. Aroma is very faint, some coffee and something sweet. Taste is spicy, hoppy, and just a tad bitter (and I mean that in a good way) - roasted coffee, maybe some dark chocolate. Good stuff.

Founders Black Rye fits in the mold of a stout with a spice kink. Almost no aroma rising from a dark pour and an adequate head. Taste has a nice mix of chocolate, coffee and toffee.with bit of a spice kick in the end. Black Rye is a nice drinking specialty grain beer that will have you thinking of a stout.
Drank from a sampler glass att he Electric City Craft Fest!! Pours black with little head. Aromas of rye and hops. Flavors of rye and malts.
Pours near black with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, pine and citrus. taste follows nose
Bottle from Total Wine. Pours black with light tan head. Roasty, chocolaty flavor but not sweet. Interesting mix of flavors, very enjoyable.

Tap at brews. Pours dark brown with khaki head that leaves awesome lacing. Aroma is honestly not to strong, all I smell is light hops, but its also a standard pint glass, not the best for pickin up any aroma. But the taste... Is fuckin great. Nice citrus and earthy hop punch combo, and then a creamy, toasty chocolaty finish that suddenly goes to a nice, slightly bitter finish. Great black IPA.

With Zachary, pours a rich black color with no head. Nose is bitter sweet with hoppy citrus notes. Taste is bitter with strong hoppy rye citrus notes. Additionally, straight up malt and very subtle chocolate . Finishes on the same tasting notes with a strong bitter long finish. Quaff Score 7 / 10
Bottle. Pours black with a light brown head and aroma of rye and hops. Taste is bitter, lots of hoppy notes, grapefruit and citrus along with rye, malt, and chocolate into the bitter, dry finish.

Bottle courtesy cwsample. Pours a dark brown to reddish color. Tan head. Roasty sweet nose, caramel, rye. Flavor is rye bread, sweet, and quite roasty. Some coffee. Some light hops. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with medium size head. Aroma of roasted malt , coffee , some bread and citrus hoppy notes. Roasted caramel , nuts and coffee in taste . Decent mix of hoppy and roast bitterness in the finish .
Quite black. Smells like pumpernickel bread. Tastes bready as well. Somewhat cutting. Decent beer.

16 oz draft pours a black color with a small tan head. Aromas of spicy malt, coffee, light hops. Medium bodied, very nice.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black from a bottle. Aroma is burnt toffee, flavor is bitter, with walnuts, dry rye flavor. Good beer.
Great balance of hops and malt on this rye beer, very easy to drink, despite its abv.

This beer pours a dark brown, almost black with a medium sized khaki head that had good retention and left a good amount of lacing around the glass. The aroma nutty, malty, coffee, and rather roasty. However, I do not really pick up the rye in the aroma. The taste is charred malts, nuttiness, some hop bitterness but I expected more. I did not really pick up the rye in this beer. The mouthfeel is on the medium to heavy side.

Pours a nice black with a tan head. Aroma is roasty and yeasty. Flavor is hoppy and roasted. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

If this is supposed to be a brown ale, its one of the best Ive had. Roasted quality abounds, lots of chocolate, some pepperyness, a little residual sweetness quickly dampened by its bitter aftertaste.

nice toasty aroma and malt profile. Lots of bittersweet coffee and a light spiciness that melds together well. Some sticky pine on the finish. Touch of chocolate malt working in the background. Way more black than ipa but still nice.

12 oz. bottle bottled 12/06/14
pilsner glass
A: Very dark pour with a modest finger high head that retains for a couple minutes. Hard to see any ruby through this. Nice patchy lacing left.
S: Roasty malt smell. Toffee. Bwown ale-esqe. No hops or alcohol detected.
T: Dry and nutty upfront with a slight hop bite following. Overall good balance though not sure if I can discern the rye. Tastes good. Again, like a dry brown ale. A slight hint of booze on the finish. Not as bitter as 78 IBUs would suggest.. Not as sweet as the nose.
M: Medium bodied and very crisp. Pretty drinkable despite the strength.
O: Not sure what to think of this. 
Dunkel? Brown ale? Black IPA? Its OK for sure but what the hell is it?
That plus the stupid 4 pack means wont be buying this again.
On tap at Pieous. Pours a very dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast, rye, and grass. Medium mouth with toasted chocolate, nuts, roast, grass, bitter, good.

dated December, I imagine Id like this even better fresh. as it is, its like a very good spicy porter, with light hops in the finish. very nice roasted malt character and smooth body. still quite complex.
Bottle pour. Near black with thin beige head. Rye and chocolate on nose. Faint amounts of tobacco. Taste is semi bitter, with a sweeter finish. Some espresso notes too. Warms nicely.
Pours near black with tan foam. Pumpernickel aroma. Taste is quite roasty to the point of some char. Spicy rye bite but not too bitter.

Pours pitch black into the glass, with a foamy head that reduces to ring lacing. The nose is of rye and toasted grains. Flavors have definitive rye notes, toasted caramel, spent grains, nuts/legumes and finishes with a burnt toasted bitterness, albeit dry and clean. The mouthfeel is semi-active, full-bodied and complex on the palate. This is a very, very nice example of a "Black Rye" at work. Founders continues to make superb offerings in a variety of genres, all quality over quantity. Will definitely have again!
12oz bottle - Nose is grapefruit and rye. Sip adds the dark malt posse. Interesting bitterness that is driven by the roasted malts. Long roast finish.
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color with not much head. Lots of roasted malt and rye spice. Medium hop bitterness.

Bottle into a tulip. Pours black, with a medium tan head that persists and leaves good lacing. Nose is earthy, slightly floral spicy note. Taste is of spicy dark malt, almost smoky. Medium body with a smooth mouth feel. Crisp hop finish without excessive bitterness. A good spicy rye.
Mild aroma. Dark pour with tan head slight lace. Nice toasted malt almost smokey. Knitter hop notes for the finish. Good beer.

12oz bottle, deep black color, with a fluffy tan head, with a faint cocoa powder, light dark bitter chocolate, chocolate chip cookie dough nose, with some chocolate pie, faint spicy anise, licorice, light sweet grainy rye, toasted, caramel, chocolate, roasted malt accents, and a burnt toast, faint coffee, molasses, burnt chocolate pie crust, faint floral resiny, leafy, minty, citrus hop note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a smooth dark bitter chocolate, cocoa powder, spicy licorice, anise, subtle molasses, faint black pepper, chocolate chip cookie dough, earthy burnt rye, chocolate, black, toasted malty character, with some brown chocolate, flowery citrus, leafy, grassy hoppy, chocolate mint, mint Leaf, chocolate pie crust, faint burnt dark dried fruit, burnt toast, faint black coffee flavours, leading towards a cocoa, dark bitter chocolate, mint leaf, roasted, toasted, chocolate, caramel maltiness, lingering resiny, citrus, leafy, grassy, piney hop dry bitterness finish.
Bottle from Victor. Pours black tan head. Nose/taste of toasted chocolate, grassy hops, rye bread, coffee and toasted rye. Medium body.

Bottled on 12/17/14. Just a tad nervous as I started and thought about the date.
This was poured into a pint glass. 
The appearance was a black color with a quickly dissipating one finger white foamy head that didnt leave any lacing. 
The smell had a sweet sticky roasty coffee and light citrus bitterness combining nicely. 
The taste took those previously mentioned flavors to combine and spark in a light roasted edged citrus aftertaste leading into a slightly sticky finish. There also was a light spice in the initial taste probably from the rye.
On the palate, this one sat about a medium on the body with a fairly decent sipping quality to it. Alcohol not felt but might have assisted in preserving the mouthfeel a bit as a light spice came rolling out over my tongue. 
Overall, I say this was a nice dark rye beer that I would have again.

Not bad. Interesting twist combining all the new trends, rye, black ipa, etc. Spicy black ipa, with a bit of kick, and a lot going on. Sort of integrated, sort of all over the place. Id try it again, but its no go to style or beer.

Bottle. Pours crystal clear ruby black, small tan head, dissipates quickly, some lacing. Aroma is roasty with notes of pine. Flavor is light plus sweet, medium bitter, roasty and pine, with a bit of rye spice. Medium body, light acid. Meh.

Poured from a bottle. Nearly black with tan head. Splotchy lacing. Aroma is coffee, roast, bitter chocolate and some licorice. Bold flavors - similsr to nose along with ash and nutty flavors; bitter dry finish Medium bodied, soft carbonation. Flavorful and interesting beer.
Pours near black with tan head and nice lacing. Aroma of rye, malt, coffee, and dark cacao. Taste is the same. Full of intense flavor. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with medium beige head and some lacing. Aroma is citrus, earth, roast malt, and a little pine. Medium body and carb with a creamy texture. Solid bitterness up front that is nicely rounded out by a little sweetness and hints of chocolate and nuts. Really complex and interesting brew. Another great one from Founders.

Bottle. Pours black brown with fast fading head. Nose is dark roast malts, citrus hops. Medium body with lightly bitter roast and bitter green hops. This was solid and satisfying with light chocolate malts and nutty characteristics.
Pours dark chocolate with malt lacing. Earthy, woody with spruce and a hoppy finish as described. A real surprise as the aroma leaves no hint of the finish. A very nice brew indeed!
Solid black ale in style. Some pine, bit of chocolate roast, nice full mouthfeel but still drinkable. Not bad.
Draught. Dark brown with small foamy beige head, caramel-rye aroma, low carbonation, mocha taste with a bit of hops at the end, long finish. A nice brew!
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2015 Nice light drinking beer, not worth the extra cost associated with most founders beer. Hops, bitter, smooth, carbonated, barely. Nice but simple, not a go to

Black colored body, medium to thin tan head, spotty lacing. Roast, dark chocolate, earth, pine, and stone. Medium bodied, semi-dry throughout with moderate to lively carbonation, moderate bitterness.Like the use of de-bittered malts.
Bottle. Aroma of licorice, citrus, and coffee. Bitter citrus and roast grains in the taste. Very good - as expected from Founders.

Founders has blown me away again. This beer just has that "Founders" taste. Rich, thick and robust. Dark, well balanced and wonderful. It seems they can do no wrong. I will continue to find a beer I do not like from them.

12oz. bottle. Black pour with a small tan head. Roasted malts and pine for the nose, with cocoa in the background. Nice blend bitterness and sweet malts for the opening. Some mildly burnt malts, cocoa and ash. Continued bitterness with a dry finish.

Bottle at home. Delicate aromas of spice, pumpernickel bread, piney hops. Surprisingly light bodied. Layer upon layer of rye spice, milk chocolate, pumpernickel, ash, white pepper, sage and mint, pine. Moderately bitter finish. Very complex and tasty.
Bottle. Black pour with some head. Roasted and herbal with chocolate aromas. Flavors are dry chocolate with some roasted tones, herbal hop tones as well.
Black pour with thin brown head. Sweet and toasted aromas. Taste some nice hop bitterness up front, with some smoked, coffee notes in a relatively clean finish.

pours dark brown to black, the head is brief and it doesnt leave much lace. The aroma is charcoal, coffee, rye, and hops. The flavor is mild on the front, then the roasted malt and hops flood the tongue. Nice.

Bottle at home while visiting Jacksonvile. Pours a coke colour with a tan head. Light toffee, grass, toast, minerally aroma... Medium body, medium carbonation. Light treacle, light bitter espresso, light dark choc, light orange, liquorice, light pine, woody resin, lemon... Dry bitter finish. Its tasty enough.

Black out with a beige head. Aromas of pine and roast. Like a hoppy Porter. Taste is roasty chocolate and hops. I really get hoppy Porter from this. Pretty good.

Bottle from, I believe, Clownoisseur. Thanks again! It pours dark brown with a light brown head. The aroma is piney and toasted with lighter notes of cocoa and coffee. Good dry, malty rye character. The flavor has more spicy, piney hops, light cola notes and caramel sweetness. More rich chocolate and rye character near the finish which also has a good amount of piney bitterness. Good body. Great flavor. A winner that Im glad I finally had the chance to try.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lasting tan head. Aromas of roastiness, rye, pine and earthiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of rye, earthiness, pine and light roastiness with a smooth dry bitter lingering rye finish.
Tap at whole foods. Pretty black with a beige head. Aroma of pine, rye, and roast. Taste is bitter and roasty and a touch spicy. Medium bodied.
Draft at church publick NYC. Pours a deep black color with a thick head. Taste is slightly hoppy and rye tasting. Interesting but very good. Almost line a black iPa

On tap at Stanley's : The sweet aroma rises from a black pour supporting a lasting thin tan head. The taste is pleasing citrus (grapefruit) accompanied by a nice balance of subtle malts and hints of chocolate. Medium body and medium carbonation. Overall, a rewarding balance of flavors.

Draft at the Dixie Grill and Bar in West Palm Beach. Snifter. Pours a stout black with an active two finger head. Aromas are rye, roasted malts hint of chocolate, and dark breads. The taste is up front rye, serious roasted malts, some pine cone, and dark bread finish. Active carbonation, medium body, pine and slight bitter finish. Very tasty.
Im not a huge fan of rye in my beer, but this one won me over. The rye is a supporting character, not the star. Kind of like a stout, kind of like a black IPA. Very complex.

Its a dark rye beer, not as hoppy as I was expecting (I figured it would be bordering on black IPA levels) but the malt bill isnt as complex as Id hoped. Still tasty, but lacked great nuance (I wanted something like Bells/SN collaboration from last year but with a hint of Rye).

From the 12 fl. oz bottled on 12/22/2014. Must have been a nice Christmas gift for somebody. Deep dark brown to almost jet black pour with a tan head that sticks around. Aroma of dark malts, coffee grinds, rye grain, and earthy and piney hops. The body is medium and oily. The taste had a pleasant grainy presence followed by a more assertive earthy hop finish.

Bottle from the Malt Shoppe. After having an interesting sample from Hank-the-Founders guy at Whirlyball in the freezing cold during that awful Christmas week. Very dark brown pour with a beige head. Great streaky lacing. Aroma has chocolate and nuts and light caramel with some spices. Taste brings much more subtle notes; tangy spices, bakers chocolate, some nut, some black malts. The grainy rye shoots in and out. Medium bodied, super smooth and creamy, without much alcohol presence. Finishes tangy spicy with some bitterness from chocolate and nut, and bone dry. Cannot believe never rated it over the years - and happy Founders re-released it, as this is good ... 14.8

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2015 12oz bottle, poured into a pub glass. The Initial aroma is a bright fresh rye bread, and a mellow toffee that fades to a smokey, roasted nuts, cocoa powder. toffee. and cola blend with an undertone rye, earth. and a toffee note that strengthens late. The beer is opaque with a cola brown hue and a tan, foamy soft head that has an abundant, thick ring and a full, sudsy surface with an above average, dense web lace. It almost looks like a heady stout. The taste is a medium / medium high bitter and sweet - fairly well balanced. The beer is oily sticky, with a foamy, soft zip of a carbonation and a medium body. Light flavors of licorice underlie the primarily smoked rye and dark fruits with secondary notes of nuts and toffee. It finishes dry, and crisp with a light ash and crust quality. A dry and astringent cocoa powder lingers lightly in the cloying chocolate and nut aftertaste.

funky earwax and broomstraw balance a brew with powerful pine resin, chocolate and a nice chewy body and malt. deep black and great head and mouthfeel. finish is crisp and mutates. rye has its place in this busy beer. nice.

Bottle into snifter glass, deep opaque black color with dark tan head. Aroma notes of roasted malt, smoke, dark chocolate, light coffee, rye and citrus hops. Taste adds caramel, herbal rye notes (mint, liquorice), black coffee, pine, grapefruit and earthy hop bitterness. Medium body, low-moderate carbonation, dry, creamy with roast rye bitter finish. The rye is strong and so are the hops, lots happening in this dark ale.

12 oz. bottle from 4 pack (picked up at Twin Liquors- Parmer and Mopac), served in a shaker- poured solid black color when held to a light source, 2mm tan head formed with several frog eyes upon the surface. Aroma of an overly dried to the edge of burning it rye, molasses, black pepper, and hunger- NICE! Hits the mouth with a medium body, malt is very forward and its delightful with the roast, middle has a cloying bitterness that takes it to the end. I could drink a case of this tonight- if only I could...

Bottle at a tasting thanks to Dave Johnson. Pours black with one finger of tan head. Aroma is roast and dark chocolate. Some citrus. Flavor follows with nice bitterness and some maltiness. Finished dry. Nice beer.

Black pour, medium khaki head. Aroma is hops, chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is chocolate and citrus. Nice oily texture. Very smooth and tasty. Well done.
Black pour. Big light tan head. Plenty of lacing. Peppery chocolate nose. Chocolate taste. Some spice.

Extra from westmeister-thanks, West! Pours black brown with fast fading head. Nose is dark roast malts, vegetal hops. Medium full body with lightly bitter roast and bitter green hops. Prefer a bit more char in my black IPAs, but this is solid with satisfying light chocolate malts and nutty characteristics.

Bottle from Village Wine and Spirits. Roast, rye, and chocolatey nose. Dark brown, small tan head. Dark roast, chocolate, light coffee, heavy dark grain bread, and some citrus jumping around in the background. Rye and hops blend quite well here. A bit light on the tongue, but tasty enough.
Draft. Solid black IPA, moderate roasted flavors, full body, bitter finish. Great choice

At Brass Tap Round Rock. Pitch black pour with a small tan head. Nose has lots of toasty chocolate and nuts with an accompanying big pine and citrus hop punch. Light spiciness in the background. Medium light sweet toffee and chocolate and a medium heavy bitterness. Medium slick mouth with medium carbonation and a long dry finish. Drinks like a Black IPA with a bit of spice.

February 27, 2014 - on tap at Pats. Dark pour with limited head and some lacing. Aroma was hops, malt and spice. Taste was a bit roasty with some mild bitterness. Spice comes out in the finish and overall nicely balanced.
Poured a deep black with little head. In the mouth the rye is very present, balancing the hops nicely.
It looks intimidating with how dark it is. However, it is a pretty good beer. The description is very accurate: medium bodied and plenty of flavor.
Dark and toasty but not too dark. It looks much darker than it tastes but still a little too dark for me
Black pour with a brown head. Aroma is spicy rye and citrus. Taste is rye, smooth, roasted malt, burnt. Very tasty. Nice lacing. Another fantastic Founders creation. Thank you!

pours unlcear dark brown with a small beige cap showing some retention and lacing. chocolate-plenty, rye pepperiness - very nice roasted maltiness profile, wee touch of burnt caramel, spicy resin, fragrant citrus and mint, tropical notes too, tiny bit of roasted acidity. light carbonation, medium body - oily; balanced spicy-citrusy finish. drinaks like a fragrant black ipa. very tasty and good!

Bottle. Pours a dark brown-black with a high, mixed-grain, light brown head. Nose is lemon, orange, coffee, chocolate, spice, dust, and a faint wet leaf/cardboard element. Intensely dry up front, with a mixed punch of black coffee, herbal hops bitterness, and rye spiciness; its marred somewhat by a weird mildewed overtone. I dont THINK its a bad bottle, but the wet cardboard on the nose has gone full gonzo wet basement and its a little unpleasant. No sweetness at all here; this is all dark roast and dry hop. Finish is dry enough it spontaneously evaporates on its own. Good, but that mildew thing mars it somewhat.

Had this one out of a growler many years ago before my rating days and glad to see its made a comeback in bottles. This one from a quad purchased at Blacklick Wine & Spirits. Dark brown in color with a thick tan head. Aroma consists of malt, spicy rye, chocolate, caramel, roast and earthy hops. Malty and chocolatey flavor with licorice and spicy rye accents before a roasty and grassy hop finish.
ABC Orlando bottle for my birthday at Shades of Green before Princess races; awful night, good beer. Lots of green hops and dark coffee malts. A little rye spiciness too. Very nice.

Pours black with a tan head that fades pretty quickly to a nice rim. Aroma is dark roasted and chocolate malts with hints of toffee. Very appealing nose. Taste follows the nose, but adds depth and strong rye flavors and a rich bitterness. More dark roast and coffee than chocolate when cold; taste has more depth and less bitterness as it warms. That bitterness has grapefruit tones. Nutty. This beer grew on me as I drank it. Another winner from the always reliable Founders.

Pours pitch black with a one finger tan head with excellent head retention and lacing. Aroma is of coco, coffee, pine, roasted malts, citrus, and rye bread. Taste is dark chocolate, rye, pine, citrus, burnt brown sugar, coffee, toffee, caramel, and some black pepper. Has a medium body with creamy mouthfeel and a semi-moderately bitter, semi dry, long, ligering finish. Overall, a tasty winter beer that I would call a rye black IPA.

Average at best. Im not sure what they were really after. It has dark flavor notes with a strong to light hop taste but no hop aroma hardly. Sweet on the tongue but for the abv I would expect it to have more mouthfeel. Not horrible. Not to special either.

Pours mahogany tinged black into a shaker. Off white head with medium retention recedes leaving soapy lacing. Dark chocolate and pepper aromas. Dark chocolate and pumpernickel upfront turning dry in the lasting chocolate covered caramel finish.
12 ounce bottle. Pours dark brown with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, rye, chocolate, and pine. Taste is roasted malt, rye, chocolate, coffee, pine, and some citrus. A lot going on here. Nice.
Black, with a huge brownis beige head. Like coffee, iced tea, and citrus. Flavor is coffee forward, with some citrusy hop flavors.
Pours a deep brown-black color with solid. Piney hop bit of an aroma. Fairly sweet, chewy body with just enough hops to balance it off.

12oz bottle, from Dutchs. Bottled 12/30/2014, rated about 3 weeks ago.. Black color, with a good finger of khaki head. Leaves decent bits of lace. Great roast and earthy hop character. Nice bit of coffee. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, crisp, lighter carbonation. Good chewy texture. Lightly slick finish. Nice moderate to bigger bitter taste. Lighter to moderate sweet taste. Love this. Super smooth, easy-drinking and flavorful. All of the earthy hops and roast, coffee malt flavors that I love from a perfect black IPA. Mild spicy grain rye is a perfect addition; rye repeatedly proves that its at home in a black IPA. I heard this was good, but it beat my expectations. Fantastic super-long finish. The malt profile and body kind of reminds me of Founders Porter -- these guys really know how to brew a dark beer. Glad they decided to distribute this one. Will be recommending, and probably repeating. Surprisingly easy to drink, it disappeared quick. Id love to see an imperial version of this Future Backstage maybe please?
Pours a dark brown with tan-ish head. Pine, some roasted nuts, and a little floral note on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with more hop resin. Lots of hops for a dark ale.
Pours black. Aroma and taste are chocolate and rye with a medium bitter finish.

On tap at Sidetrack in Ypsilanti. Sight hoppy/malty aroma. Pours an almost pitch black. Nice hoppy flavor with a perfect finish. Light and intense at the same time.

Poured from bottle into shaker..Pours black with a nice head that falls fairly quick, decent amount of lacing. Smells roasted, coffee and chocolate. For something so dark and flavorful with 7.5 abv a real easy drinker. Highly recommend!

Thanks to John for sharing the bottle!  Intense bitter-roasted beginning. Very malty bitter. Great depth. Intense body. Lots of intense deep dry roasted malt, great bitter hopped. Intense fresh, long intense but easy to drink dry and roasted aftertaste. Great.

Many thanks to John! The beer pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head. The Smell is roast, citrus. The taste is roast, touch of alcohol, citrus, chocolate ending dry and roast. The body is light/medium with fine carbonation.

Pours warm sable with a thick and frothy light tan head; a peep of ruby-brown light comes through at the bottom of the glass. 12oz bottle. Pours a deep black with a tan head. Delicious roasted malt flavors, notes of chocolate and rye.

Pours dark brown, small white head. Smell is hoppy, dark malts. 
Taste is bitter, dark malts, some coffee. Ok. Dont get the fuzz around this, very comparable to a black ipa tbh
Pours black with fluffy tan head. Very nice. Aromas are spicy rye and citrus hops. Lots bitter malts going on here with some rye and juicy fruity hops. Good stuff.

This beer pours a very dark brown that is quite clear, but there is a large tan-colored head that fades slowly. The aroma blends rye, roasted malts, and grassy hops, and the taste is quite umami, mildly bitter, and a touch sour with a roasty finish. The palate fuses a slick texture, medium body, and a soft carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2015 Rich, dark aroma of coffee, dark choc, manure, pumpernickel bread, rye, and lots of earthy, piney, spicy hops. Its both very cerealy and roasty, all in a very bucolic sort of way. The mouthfeel is medium to thin, with a medium, slightly watery body and moderate carbonation  really not as consistent as the abv or the intense maltiness of the beer would suggest. The taste is respectably bitter, with a bit of a twang and a dry finish. Grass, spruce, espresso 75% dark chocolate, rye, peanuts, and floral hops all show up in the aftertaste. Great beer  this is what I always imagined the ideal black IPA would taste like, but it could also pass for a shamelessly hoppy porter.

12 oz bottle, no date code.,br>Very dark brown, almost black, ruby highlights. 1 finger head, sticky lace. Aroma is rye bread, piney hops, subtle sweetness.Flavor is toasty, nutty, spicy rye, coffee, light hop finish.

Brown almost black pour with a quickly disappearing oatmeal head and a decent amount of lacing. Nice aroma of chocolate, coffee and citrus and pine hops. Only drawback is it is a little light. Brilliantly black with a light toffee head, pleasantly foamy. More caramel Malta and rye spice than the hops I've been told to expect.

Hops do show up in a subordinate but notable way and turn this black eye ale into something special. Medium bodied but bold with a biting, spicy finish make this a tasty and drinkable brew.

My heartfelt thanks to Founders for bringing back this smashing beer -- I hadnt found it prior to its 2015 reintroduction. 12oz bottle in a tulip. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma of piney hops, some roasted and darker malts, hints of rye and grains, and some dough. Flavor the same with sort of a weird blend. Average texture. Not great.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2015 This is really nice. Super dark pour three fingers of foam, nice roasty malts, but not too much bitter from them. Chocolate in the middle, and a rye twang in the aftertaste. Nose has chocolate and a touch of roast. One of my favorite black * ales.

On tap at Republic Uptown. Tulip glass. Deep black color. Slight tan head. Roasted notes come forward in the aroma. A slight funk with malts as well. Probably the highlight black rye Ive tried thus far. Another Founders success.

12oz bottle pours a dark brown/black with a large tan head. Aroma of bakers chocolate, rye and hop spice, and some nuttiness. Tasted of malted chocolate, toffee, dry hopped spice, rye, nutty, with a dry bitter finish. Nice!

Pours black with a medium light tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, faint coffee and piney hops. Taste is, again, really rich roasted malts followed by grapefruit and some hoppy bitterness for the finish. The rye adds to and complements the overall richness. Nicely done full bodied ale.

From the bottle pours a thick pitch black with 1.5 finger light brown head. Nose is coffee, oatmeal, toast, bread. Bottle. Pours a black color with off white head. Rich chocolate, piney, malty, sweet aromas. Roasty yet spicy and piney flavors. A lot of flavor, but it finishes with a very dry crisp finish. Very solid.

Purchased at Bottles and Cans in Chicago, IL; enjoyed at home battling through the winter prior to recording a musical project. Bottle to SA. Deep brown with moderate tan head. A: roasted malt, pine, rye, toffee. T: bitter chocolate malt, grains, rye spice, pine. Lingering dry roasty malty finish with burnt cocoa notes. Nice.
Bottle. Black with a thick tan head. Aroma is pine, dank, citrus and roasted malt. Rye becomes more prominent in the taste along with some mango. Medium sticky mouthfeel. Very good.

Some roast and a little interesting rye aroma. Pours black with OK head and lacing. Light bitter finish. Well balanced and decent but not a huge beer, and not particularly memorable. Tap at Churchkey.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt, spicy rye, roasted grains, charred malt, light smoke. Rich chocolate, roasted malt notes with spicy rye and hoppy notes. More of a dark beer (stout) than IPA. Delicious.

Pours black with small tan head. Aroma of piney hops. Velvet mouthfeel with a toasty chocolate malt finish.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Very light and mild hoppy aroma. Kind of surprised how mild it was. Light bitter and roasted malts with it. Dry and bitter hops at the start with an astringent middle and a bitter and roasty finish.

Pours black with a small tan head that quickly dissipated to a trace film. Aroma is roast, citrus, floral, dark chocolate and nutty. Taste is moderate bitters that are quickly tempered by a little sweetness. Smooth and oily texture. Overall this is a fantastic beer for a cold winters eve.

Bottle. Near black with a tan head. Piney hop, graham cracker, rye and earthiness. The flavor is dry with a light piney aftertaste. Body is medium with a smooth feel.

Black and opaque at the edges, like motor oil, but the head, which is thick, medium-coarse, and frothy, is a light brown (between a standard porter and stout.) Founders Black Rye is apparently an older recipe in the days before Black IPAs were en vogue. Drinking it today it seems exactly like a beer of that style rather than the supposedly unclassifiable brew it purports to be. The rye is subtle here; subtle to the point that its an afterthought rather than one of the central flavor characteristics. Though, its a beer like this that goes to show that styles really dont mean jack, and an excellent beer should be appreciated for its excellence.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a goblet. It was bottled on 12/12/14 and cost $4.95 ($0.41 per ounce).

Appearance: Ink black color with blood red highlights. Pours to a small, tan, foamy head which retains and laces fairly well.

Smell: Strong dank/piney hops plus dark malt character.

Taste: Theres a certain flavor combination of hops and dark malt that works so well. That synergy of dank, resiny, piney hop bitterness and bitter, roasted malt just work wonders together. Both are present immediately on the palette here. Up front theres dank bitterness followed by bittersweet dark chocolate flavor with a hint of espresso through the middle. As good as the first half is, the second half is even better with strong bitterness and an almost luscious piney/sappy taste. The label indicates the beer is 78 IBUs and its quite clear thats no exaggeration. The hops certainly are the focal point, though the malt base is strong enough to keep the palette balanced. Oddly enough, there isnt much distinct rye character except for some spiciness on the finish. Its a good way to end this delectable palette, though Id like to see it used more prominently (especially considering the name of the beer).

Drinkability: This is probably the kind of beer most people would consider to be on the bigger side. At 7.5% ABV, Founders Black Rye isnt exactly a session brew. That being said, its not gentle sipper, either. Its full-bodied for sure, but the mouthfeel is a bit crisper and cleaner than youd expect. No sticky, syrupy texture to speak of, and a good amount of carbonation to scrub itself clean. Works great as a nightcap, though I could see it pairing well with a savory dinner.

Bitterness might be rated at 78 IBU, but this beer is NOT particularly bitter. Mouthfeel is light to medium, and Founders Black Rye finishes semi-dry and drinkable. No alcohol showing up in the aroma or flavor. If I did not know this beer contained rye, Id never think of it. This beer is similar to many other run-of-the mill, hop-resin ales of the last four or five years. I would not pick this one to introduce a Coors Light drinker to craft beers, since Coors Light is arguably better than this. Yes, I think it is better, on second thought. RJT

Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, brown bread, floral, grass, and floral/roasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/pine hops and moderate roasted/bready malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, brown bread, floral, grass, and floral/roasted earthiness. Good amount of pine/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon/orange zest, pine, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, spicy rye, brown bread, and floral/roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate roasted/bready malt sweetness; with a great malt/bitterness balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, crisp, moderately sticky, and lightly creamy/bready mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent black rye IPA style. All around great complexity and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate roasted/bready malt sweetness; and very smooth and crisp to drink for the ABV. A very enjoyable offering.
12oz bottle to shaker. Aroma of roasted malt and bright hops. Big roasted malt flavor. Less rye than expected but some definite spicy rye there on the finish which is dry and crisp.
Bottle. Dark brown color with cola head. Spicy hop aroma slight pumpernickel bread. Taste is citrus hop with a sweet grain spice

#50 Founders beer. Aroma is deep roasted malt, very light hops. Appearance is very dark brown, light brown head. Taste is very deep malt, some rye, very roasty. Mouthfeel is nice, a touch carbonated but it mellows out, the rye is very spicy. Overall, I like it quite a bit. A good number 50.

On tap at Founders. The pour is a really dark brown/light black with some mahogany around the edges. There is a light tan collar of head and some spotty lace. The aroma is very malty. The rye comes through in a big way on the back end. I also like the roast as that becomes really prominent in the middle. The flavor is surprisingly bitter. There is a strong roast and a good spiciness that I was hoping for. The rye on the back end is really good. The mouth feel is light, but well carbonated with a strong bitter malty finish

Draft at Founders - pumped about this one coming back . Pours pitch black black light tan head . Soft pine aroma . Taste is roasted coffee , faint citrus and mild pine . Delicious .

9th December 2010Very dark brown beer, frothy tan head. Softish palate, semi dry. Dark chocolatey malt, minerals and a little rye spice. Tiny bit of hop towards the softish finish. Nicely joined up and highly drinkable. A rich dark beer without ever being heavy like a stout. Nice!

Bottle shared by James, thanks! Pours near black with a grayish brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has notes of dark grains with some rye and a hint of toffee. Flavor starts with dark grains and rye with a hint of bitterness in the finish.

A complex beer.  A definite rye and dry roasted malt aroma and taste.

A nice punch of spice, but not over bearing.

Wow - screwtop cap! Thanks MisterP. There is the aroma of roasty malts, maybe light smokiness and chocolate cake.The black rye pours dark chestnut amber with a light tan head. The  flavor of a light stout roasted malts on an easy palatable body with light roasted after taste. For a few years old it has lost some of the hops but still tastes good.

Bottle generously provided by Josh - thanks!  Pours a dark brown with a thinnish tan head.  Aroma is faded, earthy hops, rye and sweet malt, biscuit, and slight raisin sweetness at the end.  Taste is dominated by the rye malt and sweetness (brown sugar?) with some bitter hops lingering.  Clean finish with some sweet raisin notes.  Despite the absence of fresh hops this is an enjoyable beer and Im glad to have a bottle.

Thanks to STFun for the bottle. Pours black with a thin tan head. Roasted grain, toffee, spicy rye and chocolate in the aroma. Nice malt body, toffee, some bitterness and a touch of the rye. This is a really nice brew.

Smell: Rye, roast malt, chocolate, and a touch of orange zest.

Taste: Roast malt, molasses, a minty rye, and an underlying hersheys syrup and coffee profile. Delicious.

Mouthfeel: Medium to thick bodied, chewy, filling.

A: Pours dark as night like a stout or porter. There was an average head made up of tiny bubbles, but little to no lacing.

S: Very nice aromas with this brew. You could smell the nice spiciness of the rye. There were also notes of milk chocolate, and the sweetness of caramel.

T: Wonderful brew. It knocks the socks off of reds rye. There is a wonderful balance of spicy charred malt and malty sweetness. The taste is as complex as the smell. Bitter sweet chocolate, mild spice and coffee dominate. There is an underlying brown sugar like sweetness that helps to pull it all together.

M: Medium bodied and very smooth.
On tap at the Founders. Awesome Black color with a dark tan head. Taste of hops and rye. Seems to taste better as it warms up.
Bottle. Pours an amber body with a tan head.  Some floral hoppiness, a bit nutty whit some light roasted malt, and a thin rye flavor.  A hint of coco and a mild etoh warming.

Pitch black coloured body, fully opaque with a nice sized brown head. Aroma of hops, roasted malt, rye and a bit of nuts. Medium-bodied; Pungent hop flavour at first fading to that astringent and overpowering rye flavour. This is exactly why I dont eat Rye bread. Aftertaste shows some mild coffee and chocolate flavours, some nuts and that god-awful rye. Overall, good if you like Rye beers and like hops...but bad otherwise! I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Merchants in Dearborn, Michigan on 10-July-2005 on the Eastern Shore of Virginia.

Bottle, received in a trade.  Black pour with lots of light brown head.  Aroma is peppery bread, some sweet chocolate, light roast and sweet oats.  Flavor is the same, very good blend of sweetness and dry roast / peppery bread.  Soft palate.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with yem25.  Pours just about black with a moderate tan head that lasted until mid-glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of chocolate and rye.  The flavor is equally nice with more rye than chocolate.  The flavor reminds me of my pumpernickel bread, which I include cocoa powder in my recipe.  Some mild dryness at the finish.  This is a different and very enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 Growler,draught. Nice black pour with a tan head. Looks like porter,smells like hops,chocolate,and  sweet rye bread. The flavor is awesome,like others have said here..kind of like IPA meets stout,and the flavor changes throughout the glass,some coffee,and dark bread notes, awesome smooth mouthfeel, and a crisp hop finish...my burps tasted like hops. Founders does some mind blowing things with rye.  The Bomb !

From 5/25/08.  I bought this from Lone Hill Liquors in Los Angeles on a trip. I figured I should just go ahead and try a single while I still could since I heard this is retiring for a while.

It pours quite a bit darker than cola brown with a tan head that fades quickly. Not much in the way of lacing. 

Smells of rye and some roasted malt with just a hint of hops. I wish I had tried this a little more fresh to try and get that hop bite. 

Taste is very nice for a rye beer. Spicy up front with some breadiness and plenty of coffee in the middle and then a nice hop bitterness at the end.

Medium bodied with plenty of tingly carbonation still. 

A little too much rye to have more than a couple of for me but this was an enjoyable beer.

Delicious. The rye and dark/roasted malts play well together. Balanced, complex and spicy. A nice, dry finish is cleaned up by the hops. Slightly bitter, but rich in roasted malt and medium-high carbonation, this beer is really excellent. Could drink a couple of these without completely exhausting the pallete.

Pour is very dark with a little red around the rim, and not much head.  The aroma is strong and sweet, with noticable coffee and rye, plus a little alcohol in there too.  It tastes similar to a Baltic porter, with coffee and grains in the forefront.  Putting a bunch of rye in there is a good move, and adds to the East European character of the brew. It is pretty dry and well-hopped.  Indeed, it was so much like a glass of hopped-up brown bread that I wanted to stick a slice of ham and a pickle in my glass!  Very fine.  Thanks again to Adrian.
Pours reddish brown with a tan head.  Smells of rye bread, some spicy hints.  Tastes mildly mitter and fruity with some nice sweet spicy hints on the finish.

6-18-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to Splitgrin 
Big black pour with super thick beige tan head.  Smell is cherry sweetness and charred malt.  Flavor is sweet yet seemingly hoppy in the finish too.  So overly carbonated however, it is hard to really detect much of anything except for the Alka-Seltzer like feeling on your tongue.  Damn that soda mouthfeel - it kills everything the second it hits the tongue.

Bottle courtesy of SPLITGRIN. Thanks!
Pours a nice black color but with an enormous fizzy tan head that filled well over 1/2 the glass.  Not my 1st experience with a severely over carbonated Founders beer, unfortunately.  Smell is roasty, yet dry and not typical roasty malt, due to the rye.  Light coffee taste and rye.  Mouthfeel is atrocious and distracting right off the bat.  Foamy in the mouth and simply ruins the otherwise decent beer.  Maybe worth trying another bottle one day.

Dark mahogany body that allows light to pass through just on the outermost edges.  The eggshell colored head leaves minimal lacing on the outside of the glass.  Aroma comes through more as it warms and exhibits bitter chocolate, roasted malts and smoke.  Similar flavors and a thinner consistency than the flavor would indicate.  Bitterness lingers.
Dark pour.  Thin, tan, lasting head.  Nice roasted malt, chocolate, slightly hoppy aroma.  Nice medium body.  Good roasty flavor, subtley smoky.  Nice bitter finish.
Dark brown with a fleeting tan head. Nice chocolate biscuit malt smell. Medium body. Roasted malt flavor with a mildly bitter floral hop flavor  to finish. 51706

text: A good drink.  I tasted coffee rather than all the fancy notes indicated in the commercial description, but the hoppiness is certainly there.  Better than most stouts you are likely to have.

pour close to black with fluffy tan head and plenty of lacing.  Aroma dominated by roast & malts, similar to that of a porter. rye, hops coffee and caramel on the mouth-feel with a porter like finish.

Bottle, with a thank you shout out to Gregis for this!  Pours a dark brown with a one finger tan head and minimal lacing.  Aroma is nuts, rye bread, light coffee and hops.  Flavor bring out more of the hops, with chocolate, roasty malts, and nuts.  Agree with Tim that it has a lot of porter like qualities.  Solid, but fairly unexciting.  Thanks again Greg!

This poured deep mahogony in color, verging on black and the head dissipated to leave only some random lacing.  The nose showcases the rye as this smells like dark rye bread along with licorice, dark chocolate, vanilla and expresso roast.  In the mouth, the initial sweet smoky/burnt flavors of roasted malt gave way to those of bitter coffee and dark chocolate.  While the flavors would lead one to believe this would be a thick, heavy beer this is actually light on its feet.  Overall, this is a well-made beer though when looking for these flavors I prefer the heavier Imperial Russian Stouts.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of tjthresh, enjoyed at my Holiday Mini Tasting.  Pour is black, with a slightly brown tinge.  1.2 inch off white head.  Aroma of coffee, malt, and very bright and active hops.  Taste is porterish, with cofee, bitter hoppiness and some nutty graininess towards the finish.  Also some licorice present.  Quite a bit of carbonation in this one, possibly too much.  Good, though the grain lingered too long in the finish.  Thanks for hauling these back, Tom!

Tasted at theistis Holiday tasting.  Opened with a pop! Poured a deep black with an off white head. Lots of roasted barley and citrusy hops in aroma also some chocolate. Aggressive roasted/patent malt bitterness. Some tangieness from the rye. Long dry finish of roasted malt and hops. Not sure if I could drink a lot of this.

Bottle.  Coffee, rye malt and pine hops aroma.  Opaque black-brown color with large tan head.  Mildly astringent - sweet coffee and rye malt flavor with a pine hops finish.  High carbonation.  An enjoyable beer.

Pours the color of coffee with a fizzy tan head that quickly turns into nothing more than an oil slick. Smells of raosted malt and bread. Tastes of rye bread, chocolate malt, roasted malt, Mouthfeel is harsh and the finish is dry. Not so great of a beer.

This was very nice, especially so on a cold night.  Ive frequently found something unhappily odd about rye beers, but this one didnt do that.  There are some rich dark strains here, deeper than porter but with a lot of toasty smokiness and musty chocolate.  Not particularly thick but not in a bad way.  Excellent.

Pours a dark chocolate brown (almost black) with an enormous, dense, frothy, tan head that leaves sticky, glass-coating, creamy lace, once it eventually recedes. With a proper pour, a half inch of liquid yields a glassful of head; it reminds me of what you get from pouring root beer over vanilla ice cream. Patience is a virtue with this beer, as you will  be waiting a while for the head to diminish. Once it does, the aroma is quite enticing: chocolate, toffee and spicy rye notes commingle in a sweet-toasty harmony. Medium-bodied and creamy-slick with a moderately bitter, toasted finish. The flavor is of chocolate, chestnuts and mildly spicy rye with a supremely well-integrated hop finish. I really like Reds Rye, and this beer is even better. God, I hope that Founders expands its distribution to Kansas City. They certainly know how to make extraordinary beer.

Bottle, thanks to after4ever. Big sour rye aroma, with plenty of chocolate, coffee and brown sugar to keep it company. Medium body and light carbonation.  Taste also features rye, chocolate, coffee and brown sugar.

12-oz. Thanks, Sprinkle! Black. Thick, surging, bubbly tan head. Its impossible for me, as a certified rye freak, to imagine a beer smelling better than this. Rye, char, roast, chocolate, and who knows what else on the nose. Bodys on the high side of medium with nicely placed moderate carb. Chocolate, sour rye, and roastiness on the mid-palate. Lingering rye bread finish. Awesome stuff.

A very nice brew.  Pours dark brown-black, with very little head.  Nose is hops, mostly, with some roast notes.  Flavor is, in many ways, similar to a dry stout: roasty, rich, coffee, and hops.  Very nice!
Bottle: Pours very black with a good, thick head.  Great hoppy aroma.  Tastes like a very good and thick IPA.  I really enjoyed this beer.

This one is a reminder how much I love rye. Very dark with a nice head. Nose of chocolate malt with sweet hops. Taste has some rye spice but it helps balance out the hops and nutty malt body. Some caramel and roasted malts. Nice beer screams to be warmed.

12 oz bottle. Nearly black with hints of amber and a thin tan head. Spices and chocolate in the nose. Fairly big hop note to start with a chocolate malty middle and a very clean finish. Thinnish. Very drinkable.

Dark black pour with very minimal bubbly head.  It was quite weak and watery.   Nose is slightly hoppy with malt also coming through, but in general the aroma was quite weak (poured too cold? maybe?).   Flavor is dull for the most part, dark roast malt with dark chocolate notes.  Not my cup of beer.

Dark brew with a dark flavor. Lots of carbonation and a lively body lead off this intensely bitter beer, with just enough of a warming malt to balance the two-fisted rye. Pretty good but not quite as complex as I was hoping for.

Pours black with a thin dark tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roastiness. Not a lot of flavor, the sweet chocolate comes through.
350 ml bottle from archerliquors.  Black with creamy tan head.  Malty slightly roasty aroma.  Good chocolate, roasty, and grainy taste; reminiscent of a good porter.

The name doesnt lie. Black Rye pours black, some faint dark brown highlights shine through around the edges. A tan creamy 1+ finger head formed on the pour and stayed put for the remainder. Leaves sheet lacing. Good looking brew.

Unique aroma. Lightly roasted malts are the soul behind this beer but the real highlight comes from the dry-hopping and addition of rye. Mild chocolate hangs around with those lightly roasted malts but the spiciness of the rye and citrus (grapefruit rind) of the hops take over.

The flavor might be even more unique than the aroma. Lightly roasted malts lead into a black malt acidity that just before it becomes too much (and you think it will) the chocolate and mild lactic character take over. Spicy rye comes through mid-palate along wit ha nice hopping that adds some spice and bitterness until the swallow. Excellent!

Medium body with a light smoothness. Mild tingling bitterness from the rye and hop load. Carbonation somewat tingles the tongue.

Definately an easy drinker. The myriad of flavors make this one to sip and sip and sip trying to figure it all out. Not hugely complex but definately layred expertly.

Founders comes through with another winner. This beer is so unique and delicious I cant wait to drink another. The brewers at Founders are some of the best in the country at brewing so many different styles, everyone of them excellent.

8/15/07

Bottle: Dark brown, tan head, light lacing. Nose of deet and soap, some rye and earthy caramel. The flavor is astringent, lots of alcohol, bitter coffee and sharp roast. The finish is roasty, strong alcohol. Like an imperial stout, but not good.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 Wow.  Looks like a stout...nearly black with a thick brown head that leaves a heavy lacing.  Wonderful aroma of chocolate, caramel, and rye.  Even tastes a bit like a stout.  Deep and flavorful up front with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Finishes slightly bitter where the rye is evident.  A superb beer.

The love-child of a rich yet mellow dark chocolate stout and a thin, sarcastic flirt of an IPA.  People might say she has her fathers looks and her mothers  personality.  A truly complex mix of malts and hops that piques the curiosity and keeps you coming back for more.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a large sized head of foamy fine to medium sized brown colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a semi-opaque except around the edges no visible carbonation dark red brown colored body and a fair lacing. The aroma was malty roasted malt and toasted malt. The crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish with a bubbly aftertaste. The flavor contained notes of mild rye malt mild hops and brown malt. Delicious and one I would certainly buy again.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Pours a dark black color, nearly impenetrable by light, with a tall head of soapy tan foam.  Aroma of toasted marshmallow, dark cocoa, and a hint of grassy hops.  Jewish rye bread and toasted sesame seed also waft from the glass.  Light bodied, crisply carbonated mouthfeel that almost has a talcum-like powdery texture .  Starts out with lots of dark roast coffee and then builds to a deep chocolate rye seed mid-palate.  Lightly bitter malt tannins pack a lot of roasted malt flavor.  Finishes bitter with a final smack of white grapefruit hop pulp.  The bitterness of the hops and roasted grains compliment each other nicely, but leaves the palate a little bit thin and one-dimensional.  Just a lot of roasted coffee and high alpha hop bitterness without a lot of complexity.

poured into tall tulip.  i like this.  pours a dark black with full caramel head that stays, looks like a deep stout, very sticky and thick head, a complex nose of initial sweetness, to a coca, to malt and then the rye,  full bodied mouthfull, initial is wonderfully overwhelmingly complex, a milky initial with slight tickle on the front to a full finish that brings all the malt, rye and coca complexity around, very long aftertaste that slowly leaves, a slight bitterness is present, as you take more sips you notice the chocolate milkshake that keeps you drinking, very milky on the palate and with the swirl... good stuff...
Dark color.  Smell of hops, coco, malt, roasted coffee and pepper.  Taste of roasted coffee, malt, hops, pine, pepper, rye, bitter chocloate, caramel and a nice spicey bitterness at the end.

For the life of me I couldnt detect the chemical tinge in the aroma like Joebrew.  What I did get was rich roasted chocolate malts with plenty of rye goodness.  Deep brown color dark enough to be black with a creamy light brown head.  Roasted malt body with chocolate, coffee and a nice rye bite to it and some hops floating about for good measure.

Thanks to brewfiend for sharing.  Pours a nice deep dark brown tinged black, with a nice medium tan head.  Kinda odd aroma that reminds me of Windex, as well as some chocolate, rye and roasted malt.  Beautiful flavor of dark roast coffee, chocoloate, a hint of that delicious rye character, medium floral hops, and a hint of smoke.  Nicxe creamy finish and the hops really emerge to carry it along.  Great flavor and finish, but whats up with the nose?
