text: 12oz bottle pours out a nice dark body topped with a tan head. A strong aroma of scrubbing bubbles (the shower cleaner) Man it was hard to get it out of my mind. The tast was much better of nice roast malt. A pretty thick body great  tast.  Thanks Jake and you JERKS

Bottle:  Trade from Eithcubes - Thanks!  Near black pour with a large, unruly beige head.  Heavy lacing.  The aroma brings this beast down with a overwhelming scent of Aquanet and hints of beer?  The taste recovers with heavy roast, coffee, chocolate, bittersweetness, and hops.  Overall, Kind of dry with lots of coffee.  I still wonder how a brew that tastes good can smell so funky...

Pours black with a fizzy light brown head.  The aroma is of toasted malts.  The flavor is of a grassy hop flavor with the spicyness of the rye, along with the toasted malts.  The body is medium with a oily texture and lively carbonation.
Dark brown and ruby coloured with a medium sized head. Roasted and malty with notes of dark and dried fruit, spices, coffee and a somewhat dry and bitter finish.

12 oz. bottle pours out  a deep, deep ruby with an abundant and durable tan head leaving excellent lace - a beer cant look much better than this. Dark roasty aroma with hints of pepper, dark fruit, and maybe some espresso. Medium body and carbonation, punctuated by a nice sharpness and bite. The rye influence in the flavor is unmistakeable, accentuated by a a burnt caramel sweetness, and finished off by a spicy bitterness. A really excellent brew.

Bottle.  Pours black with a medium beige head.  The color is actually garnet when held to some light.  The aroma is chocolate with dark fruits.  I think black cherry.  The initial burst of flavor is roasted malts combined with some sweeter malts in the background.  Dark fruits are also present.  there are also hints of chocolate and coffee.  The finish is dry with some rye bitterness.  I had the Red Rye earlier in the evening and enjoyed it very much, but this one is even better.  Definetly more going on here.  This is medium bodied and effortless to drink.  I only purchased one of these but will be picking up a sixer soon.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a shaker.  This beer poured a deep brown/black semi-translucent color with ruby highlights around the edges of the glass.  A thin, fizzy head lasted for a few moments, then faded into a few lingering bubbles.  The aroma consisted of roasted chocolate malts, nuts, and a bit of light piney hops sitting in the background.  The flavor was slightly biting, and bitter at the start.  Then it was followed up by some chocolate and coffee notes that lingered.  The mouthfeel was lightly carbonated and medium-bodied.  This was a pretty good brew from Founders.  It almost reminded me of a dry stout.  Worth a try.

Tap @ Sunset Grill, Brighton, MA.  Pours jet-black with a white to off-white head.  Aroma is dominated by malt and hops.  Taste is of chocolate with earthy notes thrown in, and a sharp rye aftertaste.  Alcohol is slightly prominent in the aftertaste.  A smooth, solid beer.

Very roasty malt aroma. Some mild hops peak through. Pours almost black - hence the name - with a small tan head that sticks to the side of the glass. Lots of hoppy bitterness hits the taste buds initially, followed by roastiness, then some rye. Some mocha and chocolate are present as well. Somewhat dry. Medium in body. It tastes like a bitter porter to me with a little less body. Both Founders beers I have had were very nice. I would like to get more stuff from these guys.

Just received this brew today. As soon as I saw it I said, "Damn, that sounds good!". Sure enough, it is. Pours very dark, almost black, but not quite. Smell is great. Full of chocolate, malts, and some alcohol. Taste is much of the same, only sweeter. Finishes very smooth with a roasty aftertaste. Thanks a ton tangfoot.

12 oz bottle.  Pours brown with a huge rocky light brown head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is rye, chocolate and some tart fruits with a little roasted coffee.

The flavor is sweet lactic chocolate, nuts, coffee and roasted malts with a little vinous fruitiness that blossoms as it warms.  There is enough bitterness at the end for a dry crisp finish.  The mouthfeel is is pretty full and creamy with some slightly sharp carbonation.

Overall, an interesting and enjoyable beer.

I think you will either like this one better or the Red Rye better depending on your dark beer preference.  A porter like beer in appearance, aroma, and taste with the hint of chocolate.  The rye adds a touch of spiciness to aroma and taste.  A nice aftertaste with the spice.

Thanks to Lowe1983 for this.  Black with caramel highlights and a large, fluffy tan head.  Very attractive.  Aroma Citrus hops, roasted malts, rye, and chocolate.  Interesting flavor.  Spicy, roasted malts, some hop bitterness, nutty.  Finishes bittersweet with some smoke.  Medium, creamy body.  Intrigued by this brew.  Strikes me as a porter but the aroma has more citrus hops.  I had a great time with this brew.
Hoppy aroma with a certain something that makes my nose itch. Smells burnt, almost. Very bitter and hoppy flavored, some black licorice. Definitely a very interesting beer. Nice job, Founders!

Nice!!! Wish I would have had this sooner, but a good time to have it. Pours black with a tan head that hold. rye, chocolate, roasted malt on the nose. Taste are awsome and balanced with chocolate malt, roasted malt, rye, grain, and a great hoppy finish that last mildly.

Founders Black Rye, in a 12 oz brown stubby bottle with a twist off cap. Smell is slightly strong, like you know you are going to get an impact on your taste buds. Pour is very black with barely an orange tinge on the edges. The taste is extremely rude, like and impy stout or Baltic porter. The only other specialty grain I have to compare this to was also made by founders.  However, the red rye was much more palatable than this.  If you like those impy stouts or Baltic porters you better put this on your list to try. Medicinal back of the throat bitterness that just dont quit.  Think of beer filtered thru an old wet campfire or the taste of lye on the palate. Very difficult to enjoy for a lager lover. Will not buy again, but OK to try once. Somebody please get an Old Heathen to wash this down with. Rude and acrid, like an imp stout. If you are trying dark beer for the first time better stay away from this. Almost as bad as Lion Stout, Bells Expedition or Old Rasputen. No manners and very offensive.

text: Lots of rye and hops on the aroma.  Flavor follows though with plenty of spicy rye.  Not bad, but I prefer my rye in stouts.
This beer is interesting: flavors of mocha, dark rye bread, and bitter roasted malt.  The finish is quite bitter, much like coffee.

Bottle; poured a dark brown/black; small to medium light brown head.  Aroma of chocolate and caramel malt.  Strong flavor of chocolate and coffee; Flavor was alot like a porter.  Flavor of rye as well.  Ok, expected better

Rated 9/14/06:  Great brew here, poured much darker than I expected. Enormous medium tan head with lots of good lacing. Mild aroma slightly sharp and bitter, scents of chocolate malt and sweet caramel. Creamy and thick to the mouth good feel to this. Flavor resembles a light porter or sweet stout. Nice bitter hop flavor with a sharp graininess, which could be the rye. This is my first rye brew, and what a great one indeed.

Pours a dark brown almost black with a thin tan head. First thing you smell is Fresh Hops ! also scents of malt, toffee and fruit. The flavor is incredibly well balanced with a creamy palate, with notes of chocolate, caramel, coffee, malts, and ginger.

Bottle.  The cap literally popped off the bottle and foam erupted from the bottle when I cracked this one.  This has happened on several occasions with Founders Rye beers (Reds and Black).  Appearance is black - very stout-looking.  Huge fluffly off white head.  Very much a well balanced IPA or possible a strong ale, in my opinion, with a dark color and rye highlights.  The rye is not overpowering at all very subtley balanced.  A terrific beer - I would expect nothing less from Founders.
well hopped and roasty, though not a ton of rye character. A bit of anise, but mostly hops. okay, not great.....

Poured into a pint glass. Dark brown colour with a medium tan frothy head that starts lacing the glass near instantly. The aroma is a powerful, chocolate-coffee, roasted malts. The flavor is blended with toffee, chocolate, hints of rye,  and coffee. Finishing flavour combines together with the roasted malts and earthy slight bitterness. Complex and different, very delicous brew.

Pours a dark brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is of rye, chocolate, toasted malts, a hint of coffee, toffee, and some citrus hops.  Flavor starts of with the toasted malts, chocolate and hint of coffee that gives way to the more subtle tones of toffee and citrus hops.  The lingering flavor is strong of the hops and rye.  Very delicious brew.

Its so cool when your friends bring you home beer from vacations and trips just because they know youll be pumped to try something new!

Dark Rye pours a dark crimson body and a tall tan head, lacing the inner glass from start to finish. The aroma shows some oats and a nice playing on the Rye. The use of Chocolate Malts are profound, a big dose of black coffee, and bakers chocolate. The flavor is full of chocolaty bitterness with an accompanying spicy hop character that adds a long dry citric finish. A black IPA this is indeed as it reminds me alot of Averys New World porter, which was already an immense favorite of mine! 
Man... Black Rye is in fact an Awesome Beer!

Founders has finally made its way east! Pours out black with a nice fluffy off white head. Aroma of roasted malt, and some rye bread. Taste is complex, roasted malt, coffee, slight chocolate fading into some earthy rye flavors. Interesting beer.

bottle at sunset grill in alston. nice strong aroma of rye and espresso. pours dark with tan head. flavor is full yet refreshing; the rye is very apparent but not overpowering. thinner in your mouth than it looks in the glass. really, really nice brew.

Pours an inpenetrable black with a creamy, dimpled tan head. The aroma is roasty and spicy. The smell almost reminds me of cola mixed with espresso. The taste is immediately biting hops, with a roasty chocolately, yet spicy aftertaste. There is no doubt that this beer is grainy, which isnt usually a good thing, but in this case I feel it establishes a solid backbone for the rest of the flavours. The mouthfeel is a bit thin, but I dont feel this takes away much from the awesomeness that is Founders Black Rye. From the aroma to the taste, this beer is intense, just as beer should be. The lacing though, isnt as thick as the initial pour would suggest. Overall this brew is outstanding!

This beer pours an awesome head to it tat last for a while. IT has a nice dark color to it with a thick head the is very frothy. the flavor is a bit spicy with some chocolate. It is a very hoppy beer with great lacing on the glass.

Bottle - pours dark brown/black with mahogany highlights with a quickly dissipating khaki head.  Aroma of roasted grains, chocolates and very similar to a spicy porter aroma as others have noted.  Flavor is also similar to a porter though with the emphasis on chocolate notes and a good hoppy bite that gives way to a dry rather spicy finish that lingers well with the medium palate.

Dark brown pour with a large and persistent beige head.  Aroma is a nice porterish-roasted mix of chocolate and dark malts.  Taste is a smooth and delicous mix of chocolate, rye, coffee, and other roasted malts plus enough hop bitterness to make it really good.  Nice tingly sensation to complement the smoothness.  Founders scores again!

This is a very interesting brew.  Pours deep brown almost black.  Taste is roasty, chocolate, balanced by big hops, citrus and rye.  Nice dry finish.  I think they did a pretty good job with this one.

Bottle courtesy of jsquire. Tan medium sized head that was mostly lasting, minimal lacing, opaque, visible carbonation on sides of glass, and a black hue. Nose was malty, chocolate, roasty, rye, hoppy, and sweet. Flavor was malty, toffee, coffee, rye, roasty, burnt, and mildly hoppy. Mouthfeel was mostly smooth with a slight tingle. Medium body. Nice brew and nicely done. Worthy of a try!

Pours deep brown. Not quite opaque in the glass, with a large head. Very good lacing. Aroma of bitter chocolate and pine hops. Taste of rye bread. Surprisingly balanced finish. Very different. Very well done.

Had on tap at Brews in Grandville. Poured dark brown with nice cream colored head. Left some great lacing on glass. Flavor was pretty tame for a stout, I thought. Some roasted malts, some rye, of course, some coffee and even a hint of chocolate...Blended well, and definitely drinkable...Not as hoppy as some I have had...

On tap at the Beer Engine.  Poured a very dark brown bordering on black with a thin off-white head.  Aromas of spice and a bit of earthy bitterness.  Good flaovr, roasted malts, but none of the bitterness associated with them.  Crisp and a bit dry.  Almost like a rye swartzbeer, but still quite drinkable.  i enjoyed this different style of beer.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Tap at Boston Brookline Publick House.  Almost black body with an almost-see-through soft-drink appearance.  Some liquorice and lime on the nose.  Rather light body surprisingly lacking in the malt department.  Dark malts without the roasted flavours, some figs notes.  Despite being a black beer theres nothing heavy in the body.  Nothing creamy, no chocolate or coffee flavours.  Hops are of the citrusy type and provide a nice tartness.  Even at 7% thats a light black beer meant to be drank in large quantity.  Pleasant beer but at the Brookline Publick House they had both the Founders Black Rye and the Founders Breakfast Stout on tap.  The Black Rye cant hold a candle to the Breakfast Stout unless of course you have a bottle of both side by side and you stick a candle in the Black Rye bottle.

Really cool label, reminds me of Metallica or Slayer or something.  An interesting beer, as I didnt know what to expect.  This beer shared more qualities with an Imperial Stout than with any other style IMO, though there are some differences.  Color was dark brown with ruby hightlights.  Aroma was roasted malts and bitter chocolate.  Flavor was burnt malts, chocolate, hops, but was a little bit watered-down.  I would have liked more vibrant flavors in a beer like this.  Pretty good though, and a good price.

Bottle. Pours a deep dark brown color with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, spices and smoke. Hops are blended in well and but the rye still peaks through.Taste is slightly sweet intially but finshes with a bit of bitter dark chocolate flavor.

SECOND TRIAL: This is a dynamite beer.  I really enjoy the rich bitter chocolate flavors and the extremely dry finish.  The beer pours a nice black, with a modest head.  The aroma is bitter chocolate and roasted malt.  The taste is very similar: very, very roasted malt, burnt pizza crust, and a nice bitter chocolate.  The finish is very dry and leaves a bit of a burnt malt flavor on the palate.  I really, really enjoy this beer.  It reminds me a bit of Three Floyds Alpha Klaus, but its quite a bit cheaper, making it an excellent choice.  Another great Founders brew.

This beer pours almost black.  The head has as much volume as the beer itself and is dark tan.  It has plenty of retention and fades into larger bubbles.  Aroma is big and malty.  First taste really jumps at you.  Rye taste dominates and it is difficult to get past it to the more subtle ones.  Roasted flavors come out as does coffee and chocolate.  Finish is malty and bitter.  What a good beer!  It grabbed you by the taste buds and held on.  From the opening pour this was a wonderful beer experience.

Bottle thanks to bullet2urbrain. Poured a dark brown body with big head, settling down to a nice flat ring. Aroma is of chocolate, malt, candied fruit, hops and grape soda. Flavor is sweet with a chocolate overtone and slightly dry. Very smooth and drinkable. Had the sugary feel of grape soda and that dry sweet after taste that accompanies it. Good.

Bottle.  Sweetish aroma has lots of roasted malt and a good dose of hops, gritty toffee melding with the roast and some tarry burned notes.  Touch of malted milk.  Deep ruby-black pour with a soapy light brown head.  Taste is bitter roast, not intimidating, but strong enough to drive its point home.  Hops are there as the base, seem refined.  Light nuttiness.  Medium-light body.  Finish is smooth cream and malt and pleasantly - and gently - warming.  After a few ounces, nuanced grapefruit begins to squirt through.  This is an interesting mix of qualities from various styles, and if the second bottle holds the line, I might shift the score up four or five tenths.

Founders Black Rye
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in an English pint glass
Recent brewing, absorbed 02/07

Poured a clear black with brown highlights with a large creamy fully lasting light brown head.

Smelt of strong burnt grain, soy, dark coffee, and moderate dark chocolate.

Taste was upfront strong bitter burnt grain and soy with some light sweet chocolate followed by a harsh burnt, almost tar or ashes bitterness with light perfumey hops on a long finish.  

Palate was medium bodied, oily, lively carbonated and strongly astringent.


Overall, a lot of burnt dark taste, not all that pleasant but counterbalanced by its interesting aggressiveness.  A great standout beer.

Bottle. Pours tar, thick tan-off white head. Aroma is pine, burnt coffee, cedar, molasses, caramel, vanilla, grass. Flavor is coffee, molasses, smoke, caramel, wheat, vanilla, pine. Smooth with a tiny bitterness at the end.

bottle shared at volgons.  Dark brown in color with ruby highlights.  Aroma is chocolate, caramel, bready like malt.  Taste is chocolate, light notes of roast, caramel, with the rye seeming to come through in the middle of the taste and in the finish: spicy and lightly bitter.
from the bottle. a decent beer with some good flavor. its strong, almost stouty but definitely rewards your tastebuds.
Draft.  Deep black with tan 1" head.  Sharp.  Super dry.  Mix of sweet and sour.  Smooth, even finish that lightly coats the back of my throat.

Cold 12oz bottle: Pours a dark opaque brown color with a big, rocky persistent tan head; leave a lot of thick lacing.  Roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and dark fruits.  Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation and smooth.  Ending has a light alcohol burn to it.

Bottle:  Brown with a good white head, bread, brown sugar and dark fruits in the aroma, mellow carbonation and medium bodied, starts and ends lightly sweet.with a spicy aftertaste.  An excellent beer.

light/mod aroma of cereal, roast, pine, some must, and maybe some black currant.  taste is coffee roastiness and smooth warm breakfast cereal sweetness fading to a biscuit dryness and finishing in a citrus pine bitterness.  pretty tasty brew.

Dark brown, almost black colour with a small tan head. Roasted malty aroma with a light coffee bitterness and some chocolate sweetness. Light roasted malty and fruity flavor with hints of chocolate and coffee.

bottle. Pours a nice, dark brown with white, creamy head. Not a strong aroma, but of slighy coffee and yeast. Taste is smooth, finishing with bitterness. I would agree with blankboy that it tastes almost like a stout. A very good dark ale.

Bottle. Pours a very dark and bubbly reddish-brown with an average size diminishing off-white head. Nice aroma of roasted malt, smoke, chocolate , yeast and light hops -- smells great! Flavours malty with some smoke and chocolate and a long bitter finish -- almost tastes like a Stout. Medium bodied. This is very good, well done!

Pours black with an average tan head. Aroma of roastiness, chocolate, and maybe a little coffee. This doesnt really seem like a american strong ale at all, probably stout. This was sweet but still pretty good. I didnt taste much rye though.
Bottle: Dark brown with a big tan head. Aroma, rye, roasted malts, carraway seeds. Flavor, coffee and chocolate, some smoky notes, rye, roasty. Full bodied. Very good brew.

Bottle from Bullet2urBrain.  As the description states, very surprising.  I was expecting more along the lines of the sweet and hoppy reds rye, but found myself in something more like a porter with some coffee and plenty of chocolate.  Very full bodied.  A growing fan of Founders

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2008 Bottle, poured very black with dark red (wine like) around the edges with lots of off-white bubbles, thick lacing,
stout fragrances from the neck of the bottle, bold fragrances of dark roasted malt and toasted malt in the glass,
lots of carmel, some toffee, sweet fragrances mixed with dark candy, stout, some chocolate, smooth taste of roasted malt and toasted malt, some hop bite, touch of coffee and rye bread in there, little bitterness, this is a wonderful brew, I could drink this year round, cheers to Founders.

Pours a dark black color with a light brown head.  Crisp aroma is highlighted with a slight cola twist and some coffee.  Definitely hoppy, some bitter cocoa with a nice, dry finish.  Not what I expected!  Founders seems to have some of the better brews available, a wider distribution could spark some creative competition, of which we could only benefit!

Black beer with ruby highlights when held up to the light. Tall head of creamy tan foam. Good head retention and very nice thick lace. Chocolate, licorice, and coffee in the aroma - on the sweet side actually, but not by much.

No sweetness in the flavor however, just bitter chocolate, roasted malt, and strong coffee in the finish. Rye dryness comes into play more in the aftertaste. Medium body, dry and moderately bitter. Smooth carbonation.

Pours deep black with a huge tan head.  Aroma was roasty malts and hops.  Flavor is a lot of rye with a big hop bite.  Very complex.  I think Ill try it again before I decide wether I love it or not.

12oz bottle poured almost black in color with a huge tan head. The aroma was hoppy with roast, chocolate and rye. Taste had a hop bitterness with a bitter sweet chocolate and a sharp dry finish from the rye. Overall an interesting beer, but I dont think it belongs in the Strong Ale cat.

pretty dark pour with a 2-finger head.  First aroma i picked up was chocolate.  Also rye,  piney hops, and some roasted tones as well.  Flavor was fairly complex, roasted barley, some rye, a solid bitter hop finish.  Nice Medium mouthfeel.  Founders continually impresses me with great beers.  One of the best American Strong Ales that I have had to date.

Pours a very dark with just sme hints of ruby highlights around the edged. Theres a two finger head that settles slowly to a thick cap, leaving behind thick clumps of foam on my glass.

Smell; spicy rye up front, that I find very inviting. Chocolate and coffee notes are present, as well as some hints of hops.

Taste; the rye really stands, and brings a nice spiciness to this. The chocolate is a little stronger than I expected, and is joined by a little coffee and a nice roasted, nutty maltiness. Theres also a bit of a floral hops in the finish. Mouthfeel is nice and full, and almost dangerously drinkable.

Ive had this on tap before, and the bottled version is just about as good as I remember it being on tap. Hopefully Ill be able to pick up another sixer of this next year.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Pours from bottle to snifter a dark brown, almost black color with sone copper-orange highlights. Produces an immense, rocky tan head which slowly settles to a durable 1/4" coating. An amazingly complex aroma greets the nose with upfront notes of dusty/earthy hops, spicy crushed caraway seeds, rye, dark roasted malts and cocoa. Found the palate to be full, but was way too spritzy for the style. Less CO2 would have provided a silkier mouthfeel. Flavors seemed a bit more subdued as compared to the aromas. However, lots semi-sweet  burnt malt and chocolate initially, followed by a firm hit of an earthy and citrusy hop presence. A subtle taste of spicy rye grain is left on the tongue in the finish. A very unique and pleasing dark ale. Perhaps a dark IPA to be more precise. Worth seeking out for sure.

12 oz bottle. Clear dark brown color with red highlights. Head was thick, off white, and laced the glass. Nutty chocolate aroma. Very effervescent. This bottle was over-carbonated. Roasty flavor with a touch of anise.

12 oz bottle.  Via Trade with demitriustown.  Extremely beautifal pour, pours out dark brown but settles basically black with a nice thick light brown/tan head.  Through my conjested nasal passages the nose is hoppy with a nice malty finish.  The taste is more hoppy then I expected but malt notes as well as nutty and toffee flavors come through nicely.  This beer has a lot of character and from what Ive heard about Founders brews Im glad to say this does not dissapoint.
Get some chocolate,coffee and rye in the aroma.Pours black with a huge tan head.Roasted malts and rye in the flavor.Mouthfeel is a little thin with a slight coffee finish.
Bottle. Sampling this after a Founders Red Rye (which I prefered). This pours nearly like a porter and has a similar flavor palate. There are strong flavors of coffee and chocolate.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours completely dark and opaque with a dense, creamy, beige head leaving some lacework. Hoppy aroma with lightly burned malts. Medium-bodied with sweetish notes of roasted malt and a lightly burned, coffeeish edge. Very soft mouthfeel. 291206

Bottle.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Roasted aroma of coffee, hops and dried fruits.
Roasted flavour of coffee and hops.

Draught. Pours black with big beige head. Aroma of hops bigtime. Flavor is roasted malt all the way with some slight chocolate and what taste to me like northern brewer hops and lots of them, real grean leafy taste to the hops. Kinda of like an IPA with a good amount of roasted malt to it, different but not bad.

Bottle thanks to Mads. Black colour with a beige head. The aroma has a lot of chocolate, malt, is light roasted, so is the taste, also with chocolate and malt and some coffee. Medium body with a smooth dry finish.
Interesting brew, 12oz bottle bought by tip from Chucks employee. Very dark pour with little to no head. My best description is a nice bite over a nice stout. a good beer to drink all the time.

Toasty aroma, wheats. Flavor is chocolate, wheat, thick malts, and a surprisingly stronger hop bite than i was expecting. I didnt expect it to be this good. What can i say, Founders rocks. I cant wait to try some more of their beers.

Bottle from Paul (blankboy) Thank you.  Pours out a dark brown to almost black color without much of a head at all.  Smell is chocolate and some rye with a touch of coffee.  Taste is hopped up and sweet with some rye making its presence known as the beer warms some.  Not as good as Red Rye, but this is truely a unique offering as I can say I have never had any other beer like this one before.

Poured an opaque balck with a rocky lasting light tan head.  Aroma is of burnt toast, fresh raosted coffee and spicy hops.  Flavor starts out with a sweet burnt combonation then a light toffee and dry roasted peanuts.  An herbal and spicy hop flavor is very apparent in the finish along with a moderate bitterness.

Black pour, thin cream head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee roast. Flavor is full and rich, roasty chocolate.  Note sure where the rye is, but Im also not sure this beer really needs anything more. Delicious.
12 oz bottle. Just shy of black with a big tan head. Big malty nose, roasty chocolate and coffee, rather hoppy. Roasty flavors, coffee and mild chocolate. Mildly bitter finish. Very good.

Very big head on black. Raw chewy hop aroma. Flavour is like an inspired Black and Tan. (Guinness and Hophead). Roast chocolate finish. Every time you figure it out the beer changes and surprises you. Very cool!

Bottle.   Pours a dark brown almost black with a huge off white head, nice lacing.   Aroma is hops, chocolate, coffee,roasted malt, cola.   Flavor is malt, yeast, nuts, some floral qualities.   Palate is medium bodied, medium to highly carbonated, bitter chocolatey finish.

Bottle courtesy of Tpaliga: Poured a medium black color ale with a medium foamy head with average retention. Aroma of hops is dominant with some traces of malt being noticeable. Taste consists of predominantly citrus hops with a bitter finish and some light roasted malt. Body is a bit thin IMO and rye is very hard to detect. I would have appreciated a bit more complexity and less reliance on hops personally.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2007 Black color. Nice mix of hop and rye bitter/sour with roasted malt flavor. Medium body and low sweetness make this the BEST dark beer that Ive tried. IMO, this is the perfect blend of hops and roasted malt!

A nice looking pour. Coca Cola black with a nice sized tan head. IPA meets Stout...  A good hop aroma and flavor with a nice mix of malts and roasted flavors. A little bitter. A little dry. A little crisp. Alot good!!!

Black, as advertised, with a thick tan head.  Great rich malt aroma, smells of hops, chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. Medium to heavy body, with a sharp hop bitter.  Reminds me of a good porter, despite the classification.  A bit bitter in the finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: 12 oz bottle, thanks to OhioDad for another goodie!  Pours - as advertised - a black color with cherry highlights and a huge foamy tan head, in fact the head practically jumped up the edges of the glass and over the rim as I poured!  Lots of roasty, sweetness in the aroma, like a burnt chocolate toffee, with herbal notes, a bit of oromatic woodiness - maybe cedar, and hint of spice.  Roasty, sweet, hoppy flavor, quite unique and good, bitterness is present from both the malt and hop elements, coffee sweetened with brown sugar, a bit of biting herbiness and an oversteeped black tea finish.  Medium body and creamy, fuzzy carbonation.  Quite good!

Bottle: Thanks Kenb for this one. Poured a dark brown color with a pretty sizeable amount of head. The head seems a bit odd, so I will note it. The head was very large and seemed to have quite a bit of foam that collapsed very quickly. I have never seen anything like it, but I am pretty sure its nothing like an infection. Smell is very interesting too. Theres a smell of a bit of candy, I think. Also seems to have a bit of nuttiness in this one. I can defintely smell the rye in this one. Taste is one of burnt malt, with a touch of rye in there. I taste just a hint of coffee flavor in this one as well.

Strong coffee aroma with bits of chocolate, roast, and a tad doughy.  Pitch black, with a small and bubbly lasting head.  Big malty coffee flavor with a bit of hop bitterness. Good full body and creamy texture.  A great beer!

Im sitting @ Founders as we read. My nose is not working so I am giving a 5 for nose good reason. Its a nice mouthfull, nice balance... aint all that nice. Bottom line is this is yet another great beer coming out of a great brewery. Black is B E  A utifull!!

Color is what the label says...black.  Tan, sticky foam head has good staying power.  Aroma is great!  Roasted malt, caramel, and chocolate.

Flavor is definitely roasted malt with a bite of bitterness.  This has that burned pizza crust taste that I love!  A very, very good beer.

Im already a huge fan of the red rye, and Ill definitely be buying a six of its darker cousin.

Bottle provided by ragallachMC.  Pours a dark brown with black notes, a large frothy off-white head and lined lacing, head is mostly lasting.  Aroma is sweet medium dark chocolate roasted malt (cookie) and nuts, yeast (dough) and caramel present at the end.  Medium sweet chocolate milky malt and yeast flavor, roasted malt and toast notes, nutty hints, mild acidity and bitterness.  Medium bodied, clean and fizzy, refreshing palate.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  The aroma has notes of toasted malt and rye.  Flavors of toasted malt, roasted bitterness, rye, and a nuttiness are evident.
12oz bottle.  Dark brown hue with a slight red highlight.  Syrupy, malty, bready bitter rye aroma.  Spicy bitter malty flavor.  Rather full bodied.  Bitter rye malts, bitter hop finish.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 black with red edges and a tan head. amazing thick foamy lacing. strong espresso cocoa aroma with a nice dose of piney green hops. nicely balanced bittersweet espresso cocoa flavor with piney green hops and the rye adding a nice spicy note. medium body. creamy carbonation. nice bitter spicy finish. very nice hopped up porterish beer with a nice rye kick.

12 oz bottle via Ohiodad (thanks!). Pours a dark dark brown/almost black with a massive tan head that takes up 2/3 of the glass. Nice aroma with notes of Rye (of course), raisins, molasses and alcohol. Taste is fairly bitter with the rye trumping everything, although some hops (cascade?) are there in the finish and lingering aftertaste. Medium body. Very carbonated. Too much rye and too bitter, dont really care for this one...

Pours out of the bottle like partially used motor oil.  Color is very dark amber, almost black (chocolate colored), with ruby red tones.  Nose reminds me of chocolate covered cherries (with liquer).  Oh my this tastes so good!  The initial taste is roasted caramel and some fuit.  Then it becomes more sweet and chocolate-like.  The finish is slightly roasted, bitter rye.  The after taste reminds me of dark roast espresso.  The alcohol starts to peek out more as the beer warms up some.  This beer has a medium body, but the mouthfeel is rich, smooth, and almost creamy.  I just love rye beers (and rye bourbon), especially if it is a Founders rye beer!  Both the Founders Red Rye and Black Rye are awesome and unforgettable!  I think that the black rye might even be more impressive and complex than the red rye.  Id write more, but Im scrambling to find my car keys to get to the store to get more of this brew!

12 oz bottle, $1.79 from the Pour House Bottle Shop.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2006 Label is a nod to AC/DCs back in black cover so this better rock, and it does indeed rock!  Rye and hops dominate with hint of tobacco and wood more than nut as claimed. Some sort of slight  prune / fig / plum note. This is not as fruity as Founders great red rye but just as good. Creamy smooth rich medium body dark ale. Close to a hybrid like slabcitys stout ale.

Wow this beer is amazing.  I will suggest this one when you visit Founders.  Nice and complicated, yet familiar.  Its like tasting the ideal combination of all the best beers in the world.  Its rich, dark, creamy AND carbonated, thick AND thinnish...wheaty, malty, slightly bitter.  Perfect alcohol amount.

A hazy deep red beer with a huge brown head. The aroma is sweet roasted malty with quite a lot of hops, giving it a light citrusy note. The flavor is sweet malty and both light notes of roasted malt and chocolate.

Bottled. Black brown coloured. Fluffy. Brownish head. Chocolate, sweetness, fruits, flowers and light spices in the aroma. Flavour is roasty, chocolatish, herbal  and light berries. Full bodied. Light bitter and roasted end. Quite dry. Thanks to BBB63 for the trade.

12oz bottle, maybe a year old. Pours damn near black with a reddish tint. Bottle conditioned. Small, bubling foam. Aroma is cocoa. Taste is roasty at first with a medium amount of earthy hops. Lingering roast and bitterness. Enjoyable, not overly complex. Thanks Hemmer77!
Bottled. Very dark brown coloured. Malty aroma with some hoppiness. Sweet and quite roasty flavour with fruity notes. Well balanced. Medium body.

12 oz bottle.  Ebony with burgundy tints.  Big crema head dies to a crater.  Woody rye with prune.  Smooth and rich with medium body and residual carb.  Tobacco, dark rum and mild chocolate dry into rye.  A little like a porter without the  sour.
Pours a deep red-brown, almost black, with a big light tan head.  Very chocolatey aroma, like Brooklyns BCS.  Flavor is sweet and chocolatey, with a rye kick in the middle and a bitter finish.

Pours dark brown/black, with a light brown head. Aromas are roasted malt, chocolate, smoke, and rye. Flavors are roasted malt, smoke, hops, chocolate, and rye. The rye is rather subtle. This is a really nice beer, but Triumphs Roggenbock is a better dark rye beer.

Been looking forward to this one for a while, poured black, with a decent head, that was quickly gone. Abit bitter/burnt taste on the first sip, but as it warmed, it became much more drinkable,a hop bite on the finish. Really wondering what type of beer this should be classified as.... lol! Thanks to 1FastSTi for the brew!

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2007 An acquaintance from out of state brought this one. This is the only beer I have had from this brewer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized brown head. The aroma is faintly sour and malty with a light roasty undertone. The flavor is strong roasted malts with a tangy sour middle and a hint of dry rye bitterness on the finish. The finish is extremely long and roasty.

Dark cola appearance with a fluffy tan head.  Well-laced.  Huge aroma: sweet hop profile, surrounded by cocoa, vanilla, and spice (reminiscent of Alpha Klaus).  It smells wonderful.  Balanced mouthfeel, no disconnect from the aroma: good levels of citrusy bitterness at first contact, evened out by dark chocolate and a lightly-roasted quality.  Medium, slightly-dry cocoa finish.  Excellent.

This should be classified as a stout.  Pours an almost pure black with ruby highlihgts on theedges and a nice thin lasting beige head.  Aroma is of a hoppy stout- kinda like troegs oatmeal stout- nice balanc eof roasted barley, chocolate and a nice hoppy profile- herbal and citrus.  Flavor is robust with lots of rye malts, roasted barley chocolate, other roasted barley and rye malts, then towardds the end it gets a bit slick and medicinal. Nice light ashy roast finish and a good hop bitterness.  Pretty good overall.

Pours black with ruby edges and a thick light brown head. Roastiness, mocha and prominent piney hop aroma. Very nice - notes of chocolate, roastiness, grapefruit/citrus and pine. Ends with a little ash-like flavor. Very interesting - kind of like a porter/schwarzbier hybrid made with Pacific NW hops, neat. Medium creamy body with a very smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Great lacing and head retention. Excellent.

via trade with OhioDad - Pours a brown color with a big time light tan head.  Nice lacing as the head settles.  Very light roasted malt aroma.  Has a typical porter type flavor.  Light dark roasted malt.  Leans toward the dry side.  Medium body.  Very nice.  Thanks Scott.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2006 It was Style 66/70 until they changed it to ASA 2 days later Now still five instead of Four more to go! Bottle from trade with 1FastSTi  Nose was of coffee, chocolate, and rye was evident. Dark brown with a small tan head; flavor showedcoffee, malt, and rye with a nice hop bite.

(sample shared with irishboy)very dark brown with a nice creamy head.aroma was vanilla cola soda,chocolate,coffee,and rye.flavor was a mix of the aroma,along with some lactose qualities,and a bit of a hop finish.

Rye, rye , and more rye. Pours somewhat of a weak porter. Aroma is you guess it rye with a slight of malts. Taste rounds out with a a touch of bitter malts. I could see why most would enjoy it yet not my type, however did pick up on the dry hops.

Enjoyable - Im not sure if it turned out the way they intended it, but its good. Fairly light despite the dark color, its similar to a stout but lighter, less roasted, and more mild overall. Some roasted flavors, yes, but other malt characteristics are present as well. Good.
No toasty sweet aroma, no debitterized black rye malts in fact much bitterized and no sweetness. Very Roasty though, very intense--a jsquire leftover.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: This dark brown ale poured with a medium tan head. The flavor is of roasted chocolate malt, creamy and heavy, with a bitter finish.
Dark brown with ruby highlights in color and a large three finger head thats light brown in color.Aroma is of chocolate malt,roast. Flavor is fruity,spicy with chocolate and roasted notes.

Very dark brown with a big creamy tan head. Big roasty mocha aroma. Fairly dry, roasty malt flavour is quite stout like to my mind, and could use a touch more sweet malt. Medium palate (3+) is not quite thick enough for what this beer obviously wants to be but is pleasant nonetheless. A little more meat on its bones and this would be one heck of a dry rye stout.

Bottle shared with Jerc and Hogtown Harry, Harrys bottle (thanks for sharing this and so many others this night Harry!!!).  Very dark brown, gigantic foaming frothy almost white chocolate head.  Nice rye/bread aroma - lots of coffee roast.  Creamy mouthfeel - almost like a dunkel.  Tons of roast in taste, which combined with some hops makes for a nice long linger as well.  Rather hoppy as well.  Hard to describe, but I really liked it, another winner from Founders.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  Shared with jerc and tupalev, my bottle.  Poured opaque black with a large lasting foamy beige head.  Deep roast aroma, light hops, dar fruit, yeast, mushrooms, some cream.  VERY bitter taste, coffee, chocolate, cola, bitter hops, prunes - long bitter finish.  Slightly watery mouthfeel, sharply carbonated, astringent - nice.  The yeastiness works well with the roast - excellent.

(Bottle via trade with BBB63, thanks Mike!) Pours a dark, dark tobacco brown with about 2" of tan head that recedes to about 1/8". Aroma of rye grain, bread, bitter chocolate and roasted coffee. Mouthfeel rich, smooth, a little meaty, just about right. Sloppy, webby lacing. Flavor of roasted grain, rye, coffee and chocolate. Rye quality seems to deter any sweetness from the malt without making it sour. I found this pretty damned good. Has a fresh bread quality which seperates it a bit from porter/stout category.
this was a great tasteing beer black like a  stout and smooth like a ips a great drinking beer anytime

(12oz bottle) Large tan head atop a clear brown-black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, coffee/roast, some chocolate, light cherry, smoke.  Taste is medium sweet, rich coffee, chocolate, roast, some grapefruit, smoke, nut, cream, light rye, cherry.  Creamy medium-full body, very smooth.  Not sure why it isnt considered a stout.

A dark, spicy, malty beer thats also a good "just drinking" beer. Its chocolaty and nutty but zesty, just a note of citrus, a bit of floral flavor, and a lot of spices (especially in the finish). Which spices? Bits of allspice, cumin, dill (!), coriander. Plus its astonishingly light for all its complexity. Not so heavy that one will keep you from drinking more, but still satisfying. Its an exciting beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark black with a tan head with nice lacing.  The aroma is chocolate malts with a touch of hops.  The flavor is very malty. Chocolate, toffee, but then the hops kick in.  What an interesting beer.  Nice balance of initial malts with the hop finish.  Excellent beer.

Poured from bottle, nice dark head, leaves lacing on side of glass. 

Smells like hopped chocolate. 

Taste is sweet, roasted chocolate with a cleaning hop presence that keeps the brew from being heavy. 

This brew really opens up while it warms. 

Very easy to drink! Not a heavy feel in mouth. Heck of a beer and Ill have to get some more!!

bottle.  Aroma:  dark chocolate, floral, big malt, and a hint of citrus. Rye is subtle but present. Appearance:  Opaque and very dark brown, almost black.  Small brown highlights when held to light.  Small light tan head was fluffy and lingered for a bit.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Big malt sweetness, chocolate and smoke, rye spiciness, and then the hops kick in.  Very nice.  Finish is nice and dry, have to think the rye is helping out there.    Very slight alcohol flavor on back of tongue.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Beer had a slight oily texture, but in a good way.  Carbonation was good and finish was dry with little hop bitterness aftertaste.  Overall:  A very good, drinkable dark rye beer.  Pleasantly surprised by how good it is.
Interesting. And pretty good. Malts and chocolate are full with a nice alcohol kick.

Bottle. Pours dark with a red hue around the edges, with a decent off-white head. Aroma of roasted and chocolate malts, grain, and rye. Flavor is roast, chocolate, nuts, rye, and bittering hops. Good body, goodbrew.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2006 Rerate: Had on tap and the hops were much more dominant. Hurt the complexity of the beer. I would say let bottles age for about 8months to a year for the most rewarding experience. Original rate: Wow, what a beer. Pours black with tan head that lasts throughout. Smells like dark chocolate wrapped in hops. This bottle is about six months old, so the hops have diminished a bit from when I had it last, so the aroma isnt getting top scores, but I think the age has improved the flavor! Tastes like chocolate, some nuttiness, rye, some sourness, some alcohol. Finishes rich, creamy, and smokey with perfect bitterness. This is exactly what Ive been looking for- a complex beer that isnt 10% plus alcohol and it comes in a 12 oz bottle for under $2 per! Insanely good and one hell of a value.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2007 Pours a dark dark stout-like red brown with a thinning light tan head.  The nose is really very excellent.  Once is first struck by the big malt and hint of that chocolatey roast and floral hops.  A swirling really brings out touches of the rye and more aggressive hops (Cascades?) with touches of alcohol.  This is smooth and creamy on the tongue with a bit of viscosity on its own and a slight alcohol warming.  Truly pleasant to drink!  The flavor is incredible in my opinion.  A big sweet somewhat chocolately malt backdrop overwhich there is the roasty charcoal, spicy rye, liberal hopping, and touches of alcohol.  I feel like each of these flavors pick up where the other left off forming something like a chord or a "wall of flavor".  Really complimentary flavors with complexity not solely for the sake of complexity, but to genuinely be enjoyed.  Theres also a bit of smoke and the slightest touch of dark fruit.  As the flavor lingers the charcoal, hops, and rye taper off very nicely together.  I really lament that this is my only bottle... I will have to hunt down some more, without question!!
rerate: 20 July 2007
I still enjoy this beer.  Its appeared in the area regularly though, so Ive gotten to drink a good deal more of this stuff, and some flaws have become apparent, though this is still a very lovely beer.
4 for appearance still.  Dark dark brown with a subtle tan head, not much though.  9 for aroma.  A strongly piney rye pungently dominates.  Alcohol and a well proportioned malt sweetness.  A bit of roast fills in to give this some balance.  A still think this is a unique set of odor sensations, just like the first time.  4 for palate.  A subdued body low in CO2 but still a bit creamy.  8 for flavor.  Roast, sweetness, piney rye all vie for attention.  Sweet malt backbone, some caramel, though with diacetyl butteryness, give this a creaminess, though it works largely.  A hint of coffee and maybe chocolate.  A silky smooth creamy finish.  18 overall.  I can still drink this at least once a week, but its hard to call this as so close to perfection now.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2006 Dark colour, with a small bubbly head.  The aroma is my favorite part of this beer.  Its chocolatey, malty, with rye, roasty, and a bit hoppy.  There is a lot going on in the aroma, but it all works really well together.  In the flavour you get less of the chocolate (though its still definitely there!), less malt, and more of the roasty flavours, a lot more hops, the rye really comes out nicely and some nutty flavours.  Finishes with toasted nuts and some bitterness.  A great beer!

"This one was nice. Poured a pitch black and if you could find them brown edges. Okay head solid lacing. Aroma was a little flat you could smell the rye a little. Flavor was of coffee chocolate the rye you can get as it warmed up. Lasting rye aftertaste in my mouth. Solid beer."

The beer combines bittersweet chocolate and espresso with hops and grain.   Compared to the breakfast stout, it has a lot more carbonation and is a bit thinner.  Its also has a more burnt/roasted flavor and hazelnut.
Big taste similar to their Red Rye - though more of a  toasted malt edge and much chewier. Good blend of hop bite and malt.  Nice departure from the norm.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2007 Re-rate, 2/07: While enjoying this, it dropped a notch in overall, as rye just isnt my thing. The nuttiness came through stronger in this tasting, along with a light citrus under the piney hops, and then the dry rye finish stands out the most in combination with the hops. Original rating: Poured black with very thin brown edges. Nice intial head and great lacing, a pretty beer. The aroma was grainy and light wheat or rye. The flavor was of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and some resinous hops. Was unable to pick up the rye in the flavor until this warmed a little, then the rye bread / wheaty flavors came out more, especially in the aftertaste. Mouthfeel was full, excellent, actually.

Dark beer with mahogany hints when held up to the lights.  Thin brown head.  The nose is very strong with lots of roast grain, chocolate and something almost berry-like.  This is a nice sipping beer.  Lots of chocolate, roast grains and an almost chocolate covered cherry fruitiness.  There is also a strong bitterness in here that tends towards grassy in the finish.  Very flavorful beer.

This ale pours a dark mahogany color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet with a touch of rye. A medium bodied ale. Malts are fruity and sweet with a touch of chocolate. Hops are spicy and earthy. Nice balance. Good carbonation. A touch sour in the finish. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Dark red/black color, though not quite opaque, with big light tan head. Aroma is malty, fair amount of roastyness, slight nuttyness, hint of cherry. Flavor is roasty, creamy, touch of chocolate and caramel, with a real faint spiceyness from the rye. A decent brew, but I dont really feel like it totally works. Im not sure I like the combination of rye and roast barley and malts.
Pours dark and has a very woody aroma.  Flavor is bread with coffee notes, and a bitter swetness. Very good beer.

Draught. Pours bold mahogany with creamy beige head. The aroma is full of grapefruit hops with some sort of earthy undercurrent. The flavor is grapefruit, cedar, earth, and some woody caramel hints. The rye comes out as it gets nearer room temperature. Interesting.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2006 Pleasant, mild rye ale...nice and dark in body, with a full, frothy head.  The carbonation is a little bit too biting, and big-bubbled, and not as smooth as I would have liked.  Some coffee in the finish, which is also quite dry.  Mild maltyiness, and pretty good.

Very dark brown with huge, foamy off-white head - very woody hop aroma, with background caramel malt - dry dry, mineral qualities - quite hoppy and piney - the rye is very evident and tasty - balancing background chocolatey malt sweetness - a fine rye ale.

Pours an opaque black with a light tan head. The aroma holds both a lot of coffee and dark chocolate backed with a bit of vanilla and cream. The flavor also holds a good amount of coffee and chocolate along with vanilla and hazelnut. Its a very nutty, toasty beer, and while I can kind of taste some bitterness from the hops, its not too overpowering...a very light citrus element is added but not a whole lot more than that. Fairly light in body, but not too thin by any means and goes from a nice roasted malt over the tounge to a dry bitter finish. Nice brew overall.
Bottle from Rileys in Madison. Pours very black and I have to admit,I was expecting more of a roasted malt,grainy taste but was pleasantly surprised to taste all those hops.

Black. Small, off white head. Nose of roasty bittersweet chocolate, coffee, subtle hops and grains. Same flavor with more hops and more roastiness. Flavor is balanced. Medium body is balanced. Solid brew, very drinkable.

In the bottle. Black in color with a thick dark tan head. Has a chocolate malt and espresso coffee aroma. This beer has a big palate. Its very mouth coating. The flavor is milky sour at first, then a strong roasted coffee flavor emerges. The flavor finishes with a rye whiskey burn. Theres a solid hop bitterness at the finish resulting in a mouth dryness that lasts a long time, teasing you. It also has a backbone chocolate milk sweetness that really isnt too sweet at all. This is a great beer. Id call it a Rye Porter, not merely an "ale" as listed above.

Bottled, thanks heemer77. Dark brownish ruby colour, mediumsized brown foamish bubbly head. Mainly roasted malts in aroma, same in flavour. So why is this an ale? It could as well be a porter, as I have had stuff called porter which has been crappier than this. A bit to the waterier side as for the palate, but flavour is wellfilled with roasted malts, old coffee and more roast.

Bottled
Almost opaque black/brown,  good creamy brown head. Toasty aroma of roasted bread. Porter-like roasted, cold coffee flavor. Sweetness and light hops in the finish, coffee in the aftertaste. Alcohol is quite hidden. Some smoked/tobacco notes but not much rye found.

Very dark with minimal head.  Aroma is pretty dark, but weaker than I expected.  Tons of flavor for a beer that has such a thin mouthfeel.  Burnt rye, mild molasses, espresso, charcoal and dark fruit are all present and blend nicely, but fade fairly quickly.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pour is a very dark brown with a reddish tint when held to light.  Aroma has lots of hot bitterness with roasted malt.  There is also so dark bitter chocolate with mild coffee and even lighter hazelnut essence.  The tast has a nice roasted malt with some burnt chocolate.  The beer is medium bodied and well carbonated.  The finish is rater nice - very sharp bitter roasted hops.  Another quaility brew from Founders.

Pours a dark-yet-transparent mahogany/brown with a staunch, khaki head that left lace in sheets. Plenty of hops in the nose, but malts make a decent appearance... grapefruit and pine well-balanced by caramel and roasts. Hops bite your  tongue before creamy sweetness smooth it over. Peppery bitterness to finish. Mid-bodied and satisfying, I could drink these all day from autumn thru spring (theyd be a little heavy for a summer session-ale).

Thanks to Illinismitty for this.
Huge, long lasting, light brown head that tops a dark brown brew that gives up some red highlights in strong light.
Light malt aroma with nutty caramel.
The flavor is well balanced with malt and light bitterness playing out to a rye bitterness in the finish. Enjoyable.

bottle - Pours black with a moderate, fading head.  The aroma is of roast malts and a significant dose of hops as well.  The body is moderately thick and bubbly, and the flavor is of roast malt, a bit of coffee, and rye.  The finish includes some lingering hops.  I thought it could have been hopped up even more, but overall its a quality brew.

Appears a dark brownish black with a 3 finger tan head that fades into a small head.
Smell is of black grapes, plums, dark roasted malts, chocolate malt.
Taste is of the same aromas.
Mouthfeel is slightly thin, with roasted malt, cocoa, and plums battling it out along the palate.

(Bottle)  Pours a black (nearly opaque) body with a large rocky off-white head.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee, roasted malts, breadiness, and citrus.  Flavor of roasted malts, hops, and coffee.  Nicely balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2007 Thanks to weeare138. Pours a dark brown with a bubbly light brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, dark fruits, some grapes, fruity, citrus hops and rye.  Flavors along the same very bubbley on the tongue.  Picking up more roasted malts, rye, bready, nice hop bitterness.

Bottle shared courtesy of weeare138 (thanks!). Poured a dark black with a huge sized tan head (initially poured all head). Aromas of light rye, chocolate, roast and dark fruits. Tastes of dark fruits, cocoa, light rye and roast. Body was on the thin and fizzy side.

bottle. nice looking deep black body with a large mocha head to start with and then receding to a persistent small cap. The aroma is moderately chalky with notes of roasty chocolate, oranges, earth, and rye bread. palate is quite smooth with a definite rye presence among a big whack of hop bitterness which actually surprised me. It actually felt a bit heavy at times but still remained very drinkable with no alcohol presence. finishes with some chocolate roast and long bitterness. good stuff.

bought at Merchant’s Fine Wine in Dearborn in February 2006.

Has some porter qualities with the chewy roasted malts, but the plum and rosemary soapy flavors just dont do anything for me.  Has a nice char texture and finish, but the overripened fruit and maple syrup-like residual finish turn me off.  Yeasty, putrid licorice nose doesnt score any points either.

Tasted side by side with the Red Rye. Dark brownish red body (black) with a moderate head. Aroma is dark malts like chocolate, roast, licorice, and coffee... but also quite hoppy. I suppose there is some rye present as well. To me, this tasted sorta like a bitter porter. Very interesting to say the least. As I drank it next to the red, I initially thought it was worse, but by the end I liked it better.
Interesting cross between toasted charcoal malt flavors and bitter hops that just felt a little wrong on the palate, still quite good.

(02.21.06) 12 oz brown bottle purchased from Archer Liquors, Chicago, IL.  Pours brown-black with small tan head. Soft carbonation. Roasted malt on the nose. Medium bodied ale that starts dry with a hint of malt sweetness and notable expresso/burnt malt flavors. Finishes dry with lingering bitterness, roasted malt fade. Notable chalk dust feel in the mouth.  Porter-like in aroma and flavor, this ale is good and drinkable, but the surprising astringent quality at the finish was a turn-off.
On tap at Founders. Rye and hops in the aroma. Roasted malt and more rye for flavor, dry finish.

12oz - Aroma is at first hoppy, then the roasted chocolate malt kicks in with a bit of vanilla in the aftertaste.  Pours thin black with a quickly dissapating head and decent lacing.  Flavor matches aroma and is a bit roaster than the aroma,  Palate is creamy and tart.  Different and good.

Aroma:Mixe of ipa hops and rosted malt.....
Appearance:Dark with a good brown head...
Flavor:chocolate rosted malt,nutty,dry finish.....

12 oz bottle: dark chestnut with amber highlights.  Burnt, bitter hop cone aroma, with hints of coffee, roasted peanuts and rye.  A little over carbonated on the tongue, but the tingle is welcome none-the-less.  Full, creamy, large bubbled dark tan head.  Dark, roasted hop bitterness that complements the high carbonation in the palate very well.  Lightly charred raisins and burnt oak linger on the sides of the mouth.  Very enjoyable and drinkable.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2006 12 oz. bottle, also from Archer Liquors.    Pours an almost black dark ruby color with a small beige head.  Aroma of piney hops, toasted and chocolate malts, nuts.  Some bitterness up front, some earthiness, a little bit of bitter chocolate, and a fairly dry chalkyish finish.  Old rating was 3.3, and I dont know why.

text: Very thin dark brown foam head.  Nose is a mix of dark chocolate and rye. Dark opaque brown coloring.  Slightly bitter dry semi sweet chocolate flat taste. Different from other rye beers I have had.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2006 Bottle. Pours black with nice big frothy tan head. Nice dark roast, sweet chocolate, and grainy aroma. For me, I think the flavors could use a bit more balance. There are hints of coffee, chocalate, rye, and earthy hops. Finish is bitter, spicy, and peppery. Very slight warming. Another good beer from Founders. As far as rye beers go, the Reds Rye is better IMO.

Bottle from Archer Liquors. One of those beers that is very enjoyable yet its hard to get the numbers up to the relative level of enjoyment. It could have something to do with my inherent fascination with rye beers and that this is pretty much the best, and that Ive finally got the bottle that I cant at all get locally... I mean, rye is such a great grain! Rye bread, rye whiskey, rye beer... what more could you ask for. Its important that I mention this fascination because this may very well be one of those cases where something is so exciting in concept that I love it before I even try it and refuse to accept that its actually just mostly average in the end. 

OK, onto the beer. Pours deep, stout-like black with a big, crisp head and great lacing. Aroma is very grainy, with nice rye, sprouts, almonds, a touch of hopping at the end. Taste is kinda harsh grains. Rye is definitely noticable, with bitter hops in the finish. Palate is thin though also buttery and very drinkable. What can I say, I love this beer every moment except when Im drinking it. At that point its only pretty average.

Jet black with lots of creamy head. Boozy and roast stout aroma. Some chocolate. Very faint rye, nothing like Reds Rye.Creamy and well carbonated taste, toast, spice, nothing too intense. Bit of roast on aftertaste. Thanks Dr. Jay.

Citrus, floral, hoppy aromas with burnt coffee and sweet milk chocolate in the background.  Some anise is also detected.  Mildly transparent dark dark brown with a nice frothy tan head that lasts a long time.  Hops hit you right away, kinda makes for an awkward mouthfeel at first, followed by the dry graininess of the rye.  A fair amount of tobacco is present in the middle of this with a long, roasted chocolate finish.  This is well-crafted.

From a bottle that I had left in my friends fridge for a very long time, maybe a year or more!  There was a little off flavor in the beers Id had before, probably due to poor storage, but it seems to have mellowed out! This beer is much like the description.  Its extremely dark, moreso than the average stout or porter, with a light tan head for me.  Aroma is a mix of roastiness and hops with something almsot a little spicey inbetween the two.  Flavour is the same, roastiness with chocolate, malt, a little nuttiness and toffee, and behind that comes a slightly herby/floral, ever so slightly piney hop character, mostly in the nose.  As someone before me said, its kind of a pumpernickel effect (Id call it a little spicey, perhaps thats the sharpness of the rye coming in)  For how dark it is, you expect it to be maybe a bit richer in flavour, and heavier in body, so thats a bit...weird.  Other than that small discord, this is quite enjoyable!

Courtesy of Duane.

Quite aromatic. Hops, dark fruits and pumpernickel with hints of chocolate. Dark brown to black in color with creamy mocha head that is mostly diminishing. Fore is bitter and roasty with lots of black licorice notes. Some roasty and nutty asspects through the middle and more dark druits into the finish, but with a mostly bitter hoppy lingering flavor.

Pours pitch black with a foamy head of small beige bubbles.  Aroma is smoky with hints of rye and some subtle dark chocolate.  Flavors are a nice balance of smoky coffee with light hops and rye.  For some reason, I was expecting an IPA but this is almost more like a hoppy Baltic Porter.  Very good!!

Pours essentially black, with a brown head that actually faded in color to tan (first time Id seen that happen). Full meringue head and heavy lacing. Strong citric hop aroma, with notes of grapefruit. Some roasted malts also apparent in the nose, showing dark chocolate. Big chocolate coffee flavor with resiny grapefruit hop flavors sitting side by side. Light roast in the finish, with a lingering medium hoppiness. Like a very hoppy stout, but lightened in body with the rye - a good idea! Very soft palate with good natural-feeling carbonation.

Pours a black color with a light beige colored head.  Aroma is smoked hops with hints of malts,dark chocolate,prune juice, toffee and pine.  Flavor is smokey with lots of hops present as well as sweet malts,dark chocolate,pine and citrus.  Excellent !!

It has an aroma consisting of fresh cut oak and alcohol.  It is a dark brown solution that rests under a light brown head )there is just something about the looks of this beer that keeps it from having an appearance of a great dark beer).  It enters the mouth thick and produces a taste that alternates from smoky to creamy to smoky as it leaves a mild bitterness lingering in the throat.
on tap and the brewery, black body with almost no head, no nose, bitter flavor with some crispy caramel notes, nothing too bold, kind of bland with a little bit of bitters on the side

Very dark, big creamy dark brown head.  Nose has lots of rye,some light chocolate, and a bit of smoke.  Reallynice flavor, rye and smokiness combine for a good backbone.  Very dry, some minor molasses sweetness here but not much.  Very long finish.  Drinkable yet very complex.  Lovely.
Dark Brown Coloring with Sandy Blotchy Skin.  Chunky.  Rye Aroma.  Dry Rye and Hoppy Ending.  Simple and Straightforward.  Very Faint Hints of Chocolate as Well.

Pass the soot, please.  Mmmm, soot not good enough.  Soot speed too slow.  Soot speed too slow?  Yeah, for this, weve gotta make the jump straight to Charcoal Speed.
