Pours Quaker State black with a thin light brown head.  Upfront, but not aggresive dry hop aroma.  Some roasty, chocolaty, coffe aromas.  Citrus hop flavor with a grainy flavor.  Drinks way thinner than it looks, but not to a fault.  Chocolatey with a well balanced bitterness.

Pour is black iwht a nice dense tan head...smell is somewhat strange...lightly toasty with some citrus notes...taste is sweet and toasty with lots of chocolate flavors up front, then some nice bitter chewy flavors and textures come out...this is another outstanding beer!!!

Bottle courtesy of OldGrowth. Pours near pitch black. Its opaque but appears as a really dark brown. Surprisingly hoppy and roasty with light coffee notes, burnt toast, and dark chocolate. Taste is also hoppy and bitter with stronger cold coffee notes, thinned chocolate, burnt and buttered pumpernickel, light sweet malts and a hint of molasses. Medium feel to this with mild carbonation and has a sleek feel at times. Light lingering coffee-ish bitterness throughout this one. Finishes with more coffee, dark choco notes, light pumpernickel breadiness, burnt toast and light rye. Pretty good stuff!

A wonderful floral aroma with a pitch black pour and a nice tan head.  Exquisite taste of chocolate, caramel,  coffee, and nutty with a bitter-sweet tingle to the palate.  Smells awesome, tastes great, and is a very good beer if you can get it, then fricken get it.

thanks to santa my santa for this baby. not a pitch black pour, but it will do. a bit of red seen through the edges when held aloft. a sweet tan head to this bugger, damn it is thick. oak, chocolate, and cashew nose.  peanut butter toast taste with some marshmallows and wet paper. bitter finish that is like coffee bitterness, but not quite, more cocoa flavor in the finish is present and works well. a bit too dry however. this is the final beer in my red white and black tasting. damn i like rye beers, and this is good, but i may still be in the thralls of the red rye.just a wonderful bittter note to this that goes great with the sweetness. reminds me a bit of a good oatmeal stout, but not as sweet, yet better, hell im not sure what im saying except that this is a good beer.
Nice auroma and taste.  Bit of a sour aftertaste which distracts from this beer.  Fun to drink while blowing people up playing Bond games.

Bottle. big thanks tro TChrome for sharing this. Opaque body with a thin spotty wispy film of bubbles. Nose-it has that raw unrefined ricey rye nose-in a VERY good way. Taste-spiceiness from the malts, coffee, perfume, light alcohol. Very, very well done.

Dark chocolate-brown body with a thick, creamy beige head. Aroma of rye, chicory, coffee, dark chocolate, and roast. Sweet chocolate and toffee malt flavors plus a nice marriage between the rye sharpness and hops. Develops very nicely as it warms. Yet another good one from Founders.

12 oz bottle, via trade w/Drnk-McDermott.  Pours a dark brown under a minimal head.  Nice rye aroma with  floral hops, bitter chocolate, and some roastyness.  Roasty rye flavor with alot of depth.  Dry bitter finish with coffee notes.  Medium bodied with lively carbonation.  A good all-around Rye beer.  Why dont more breweries dabble in the Rye?

Bottle.  Pours deep dark brown.  Huge aroma of roasted malts, chocolates, and piney hops.  Flavors similar, with coffee and nice rye flavors and a touch of nut.  Decent body and mouthfeel.  Wonderful beer, wish I could get it locally.

Bottled.  Pour was a deep garnet with a 3/4" creamy toffee-colored head.  Some sediment suspended in there, and a well-coating lacing followed it down.  Nose picked up chocolate, piney hoppage, and toasted chestnuts.  Flavor of rich toasted chocolate and nuttiness upfront, followed by huge dose of fresh pine needles.  Medium-bodied and smooth across the palate, with a sticky, spicy, almost cloying chocolate finish.  Residual bitterness around the tongue and at the top of the throat.  Quite a tasty brew.

Beer pours very dark brown with a big retained tan colored head.  Aroma is chocolate malt and Christmas tree hops, spruce maybe?  Some roasty notes as well.  Flavor is sweet with some enjoyable toasted nut flavors and a very enjoyable hop flavor also.  Very enjoyable beverage.

Pours medium bodied black ruby with light tan head. Aroma of hops , roasted grains, and a hint of rye. Tastes  citrus, good ammount of hops, roasted grains, and a nice rye flavor.Very well balanced with a nice bitter hop finish
Pours a black/ dark ruby color.  Aroma of roasty chocolate nuts IMO.  Flavor is much that of a porter.  Chocolate roastiness.  I cannot discern a rye flavor though.  Medium body.
Poured black with very small head.  Strong flavor, stronger than I expected.  Tasted like a porter to me, but a very good one.

Poured black with a medium light tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, creamy chocolate, and a fair amount of hops.  Roastey, more chocolate, and hoppy flavor with a bitter and tingly finish.  Medium bodied.

Dark but light small head.  Lots of flavors.  Carmel and Toffee are strong but the hoppy crisp finish balances out the flavor and turns the brew from stout to ale like. Might have rye but not exactlly sure of a rye taste.  Good in the fall.  Not strong like a winter stout nor like a smooth summer ale.

Beautiful beer-nice fluffy head and great color.  Reminds me a bit of New World Porter from Avery-I like hops in a dark beer.  Doesnt totally seal the deal, but a great beer nonetheless.  Would like more body to go with all the lovely hoppiness.

Dark Dark pour from a 12 oz bottle sent by SuIIy (Thanks a bunch).  Huge head at first, but dwindled before 1/4 the glass was empty.  Still left decent lacing.  Suprisingly sweet aroma.  Citrus and apple.  Flavors were a little more malty, some nuts, but mostly hops.  Nice citrus flavor and a decent dry finish.  Pretty good.

(bottle) You know, I wasnt really expecting to like this. Most ryes are just too strange for me. But this one was actually pretty decent. There was nothing notable about it though, so I probably wont bother to have it again.

Pours to a tan head thats thick, dense, and creamy.  The body is black.  The aroma is pretty damn hoppy if you dont let the dark malts get in the way.  Pine needles, chocolate, coffee.  The flavor is a dark roasted coffee, rye, nuts, pine/citrus hops, charcoal.  Tastes pretty darn good.  The palate is really thick and creamy, has that dry charcoalesque feel as well, bitter hop oils.  I have this beer a bunch of times but never rated it.  Im glad I tried it again.  Surely makes the day go by smoothly.

Opaque black color,small tan head that faded quickly leaving nothing behind.The aroma was roasty malt with some coffee and maybe a bit of chocolate in there as well,but i could be wrong.I gotta say i like it.Roasty,coffee upfront some slight sweetness in the beginning then it changes to some mild hops and a slight bitterness.Very pleasant brew and easy to drink,not exactly an all time great but very doable IMO.
Really really roasty.  Burnt, charred.  Other than that, theres not much rye flavor as its a pretty mild ingredient.  Quality brew from a solid brewer.

12 oz. bottle, thanks to Eric ( Heemer77 ) for the bottle.  wow, another quality brew from the folks at Founders.  an aroma of dry roast upon the almost black pou.  flavor is of some chocolate, coffee and rye with some strong hops on the finish.  sweet and slightly sticky on the lips.  Nice beer, thanks Eric.

Pours with a black body topped by a medium thick head with some lacing.  Its sweet and malty with a nice roastiness, a slight touch of rye and a slight bitter hoppiness.  Full bodied, smooth and slightly dry.

Large frothy light beige head of fine bubbles.  Reduces and leaves a thick sheet of lacing.  Light carbonation.  Dry roasty aroma with a good helping of roasted grains, rye and a bit of nuttiness.  Color is a a very dark brown boardering on black.  Creamy and roasty palate with a bit of coffee and carbon.  Slightly chalky and dry.  Finish leaves a lingering dry coffee aftertaste.  Some bitternes at the finish.  Some pretty good stuff.  Thanks to Dogbrick for this one.

Bottled, while watching those "Good Guys Wear Black!" Interesting smell out of the bottle, perhaps of a cream stout with molasses stirred in. Pours deep brown, becoming black in the glass, with a thinning cola head. Taste is a deep porter, with the rye softening any possible roastiness. Cant pick up any specifics in the hops with all this lip-smacking malt around. Yet its nicely dried but not soured, and theres a touch of walnut torte in the finish. The alcohol refuses to make itself known, which can cause you trouble down the road. Much more complex than I can describe, and a fine beer. "Black" is the new "wit!"Oh, by the way:<font face=Impact, Arial, Helvetica size=36px><center>SOX WIN! SOX WIN!! SOX WIN!!! WORLD SERIES, BABY!!!!</center>&lt

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 Pours black with a creamy tan head. Nice lacing. Aroma is very hoppy, mostly pine, and rye bread. Flavor starts hoppy before the rye and coffee comes in. The end is dark chocolate. Great complexity in this one. Im picking up different tastes in almost every sip. Full-body, thick and chewy, long dry finish.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with Pailhead, thanks Kevin!) Having just sampled Founders American Black Ale, the Black Rye isn’t quite matching up for me.  It smells more like a dry stout to me; it’s roasty, but not as roasty as most stouts.  It also smells moderately hoppy and grassy, and also a bit yeasty to me.  The flavor is very roasty, fairly bitter, and even a bit hoppy while showing only a mild sweetness.  Medium "plus" in body, with a dry palate throughout, and a fairly crisp finish.  Dark brown in color, with mahogany highlights at the edges, the body is capped by a small, quarter-inch head, light-tan in color, and that demonstrates amazing persistence.  I’ve taken my sweet time savoring this beer, yet there is still a full coating atop the beer.  Lacing is modestly dense for awhile before dissipating to spottiness.  A relatively straightforward, but solid, well-crafted beer that’s been pleasant and enjoyable.  However, it’s close enough to your basic dry stout that I don’t feel the need to trade for more bottles.  I can get something "similar enough" in local stores.
12oz bottle. Pours a black color with a fizzy white head. Nose is very hoppy and grassy. Taste is hoppy, wheat like notes, finishes bitter.

Medium viscosity, black and nearly opaque in color with a frothy, anamorphic and dark tan head.  Aroma makes me its bitch.  Flagrant rye does combat with a motherload of freshly harvested hops.  Some chocolate, dark cigar wrappers and wet birch wood harmoniously assault my nose as well.  Flavor seals the deal.  Rye and chocolate malts are curt, layering on black licorice in a silent but deadly sequence.  Some burnt pumpernickel dinner rolls, rye Chex Mix chips and a hearty Turkish coffee bite.  Oozy fluidity and a palate rapist.  Everything balance-wise is amped-up like it should be, almost as if I special ordered it.  Burnt walnuts come in on the finish, along with bittering agents, espresso sludge and an oily layer on the palatary playing field.  Very impressive.  I dont think this beer could have been brewed any better.

pours a very dark almost black with a thick creamy head and lots of off white lasting lacing.  smells like a (mild) stout with roasted coffee and a very warm/rich aroma.  flavors of roasted coffee, hops and a slight hint of bittersweet chocolate lingers at the end.  very smooth and mellow and quite enjoyable.

From a 12-oz. bottle, pours a coffee-black with medium tan head.  Clear with a faint red tinge around the edge.  Fairly mild rye aroma.   Tastes for all the world like a slice of dark rye bread. somewhat roasty and smokey, with a fair amount of hoppy followup. Porter-like consistency and heft.  Pretty good!

Very near black, stiff tan head, nice lace.  Aromas include toast, malt, fruit, hops, alcohol, chocolate and coffee beans.  Flavors of dark roasted malt, coffee, herbs, dark fruit, and toffee/carmel with a nice bitter hop finish.  Great creamy texture and chewy mouthfeel.

Bottle. Clear dark brown in color with a nice tan fluffy head.  Roasty and hoppy aroma.  Coffee like roast.  Big and malty flavor. Malty and hoppy flavor. Chocolate and caramel notes. Full bodied. Well balanced. Smooth. Finish is malty. Enjoyable.
From bottle. pours dark with little head. sweet roasted aroma.  coffee notes, medium body.  Another great beer from Founders.
Bottle. Clear dark brown, tan lasting head. Hoppy roasty aroma. Big and malty with lots of roast. Some malt and hop bitterness. Full body. Nice malty finish.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Coffee, caramel, and sweet rye...but its the hops that really carry the day.   Slippery smooth and creamy texture...coating the tongue like a black oil slick (only sweeter).  Hops seem to be more floral than anything else, but still bite in the finish with a nice snap.

Nice - wish like hell it was possible to get some of thses w/o trade. Pretty much right in line with what I would expect with such a name - roasty, medium bodied, nice bitter finish. NEED MORE NOW. thanks Drew
At first there is a strong flavor rye that is kinda gross.  Then you get past it and find some smokey chocolate flavors topped with some flowery hops.  A pretty good beer.
Almost black with a big tan head. Aroma and flavor of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Really good!

Almost completely black, showing only the deepest of ruby hints.  Inviting aroma, hints of roast, coffee, spicy rye, and an attractive citrusy hop whiff.  Rich and creamy on the tongue, rather oatmeal stoutlike on the palate, yet with a spicy dry finish.  (Rather reminiscent of St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout in that regard)  This is a real winner.  Thanks Eric!

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2005 Black body with ruby highlights. The head is tan and foamy. The head faded quickly. The aroma is rich with roasted peanuts and some light coffee. There is also a very sweet note of some caramel. The taste has roasted coffee and toffee. There some nice rye in the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is slick and soft. I like this a lot. So smooth.

Enjoyed the multiple tastes of chocolate, grains, rye and slight alcohol. Aftertaste seemed a little too bitter for the general composition of the beer - and was somewhat t annoying toward the finish of the 12 oz. Fragrant aroma. Poured dark brown with a light tan, thin head. Nicely done, overall.

Poured a dark mahogany, indigo color with a small, light tan head that leaves spotty lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts, dough, and citrus hops.  Taste of chocolate, roast, wheat, smoke, dry rye, and finishing with a bitter hoppiness, and light alcohol.  Citric hop burps.  Thanks hopdog!

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2005 Bottled, thanks JCW! Near black, rich head. Vinous fruity coffee aroma. Sweet and malty, very roasty with rounded mouthfeel. Theres lots of licorice as well as hints of soy sauce and chocolate. Rather bitter finish. Complex and intense, very enjoyable!

Smooth, smooth rye ale.  Beautiful dark, stout-like, appearance.  This one is full of toasted malt (rye?) and nicely hopped like any american beer nowadays.  It is a little thin on the aftertaste, leaving it behind the Hop Rod from Bear Mountain, but damn, its not bad.

Burnt brown body under a thin cocoa colored foamy cap. Keeps a flimsy skimming and loosely thin set collaring. Thin displaced sheets of lace stick close to the top.

Beautiful aroma of bountifully fluffed espresso roast and roasted rye. Dry fudge, charred chocolate, and green hop bitterness of spruce all make favorable encounters within. Its not huge by any means, just solidly present and fresh. Love it.

Taste is wildly decadent with dark bittering tones of char, chocolate, espresso, dry spruce pine, spicey toasted rye bread, vanilla, and dry fudge. Great roasted edge the whole way through as well as the all encompassing chocolate undertone that sets the stage for the charred stuff and bitterness. A near perfect blend of darkly roasted flavors, moderate bitterness, and subtle dryness.

Clean and roastified medium quick body. Low and even set carbonation and slick even while the roast and bitterness take its hold.

Killer stuff! Loved it! Goes down with an irrefutable slooshing down the gullet. Akin to New Glarus Black Wheat without the banana - just add the rye.

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, caramel), lightly hoppy (resin).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation.

Rather sour, my least favorite aspect.  Nothing special to my senses, pretty boring stout-like beer.

Beer pours dark and mostly clear. Aroma is astringent and full of dusty malt. Flavor has a peculiar, yet enjoyable burnt sugar and dry grain flavor. The dry hopping is a little overwhelming for me, but its doesnt ruin the beer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2005 12 oz bottle-thanks to Dogbrick for this one!  pours a deep brown hue with a small beige head.  some good peachy hop notes come out at first followed by chocolate, roasted rye bread (pumpernickel comes to mind).  Good hop bitterness underneath all these cool flavors.  medium body with good amount of carbonation.  Some light ozidized notes come out, but were covered very well by the big malt bill.  Long hoppy and chocolate finish with a tad of dryness from the rye.  very tasty and unique-like all of founders beers i have had.  There is somthing about founders yeast strain that i really like.  Another well balanced beer from this company.  big thanks to Dogbrick for this one!

A brownish/black appearance. A big rye and wheat nose with some chocolate lurking. The flavor was grapes, coffee, chocolate, and of course rye bread. A big yeasty presence in the flavor. This was a good beer.

Very dark with a large frothy head and nice lacing. Aroma is roasted/malty licorice, similar to rye bread, but with a twist. Flavor is rich and malty with strong tones of rye, chocolate and nuts. Finishes with a malty rye-bitterness that is unlike any beer Ive had before.

12 oz bottle - Surprisingly pours black (Who would have thunk it?) with a short offwhite head laces the glass slightly on the way down.  Aroma is toasted malts, rye bread, and some hops.  Taste is much like rye bread to me.  Dark toasted and a little nutty.  Full flavored and very bold.  On the palate this is medium bodied smooth yet finishes quite crisp.  Enjoyable as is everything Ive tried by this fantastic brewer..

This beer is black (lest anyone worry about misleading labels) with a medium dark beige head and thin lacing. Toasted malt, chocolate and a bit of hops in the nose. Medium-bodied and nutty with lots of malt and hops flavors. The finish is dry and grassy with a nice rye aftertaste. As with most Rye beers I have tried, I enjoyed this.

Brown black opaque color with a huge foamy light tan head.  Roasty, chocolate aroma with a muted hop undertone.  Slightly smoky, roast coffee flavors with a crisp smoothness of rye.  Slightly spicy hop finish.  Mouthfeel is really smooth.

Bottled.  Aroma is malty and toasty, dark and sweet with notes of caramel, coffee, chocolate and earth along with some faintly spicy rye notes and fruity hops.  Dark brown-black color with a light brown, lasting, creamy head.  Flavors are nicely balanced throughout, with the malts contributing a bready, chocolatey, roasty, almost burnt character and the hops offering substantial piney flavor and bitterness before a dry, spicy, faintly sour finish.  Plenty of effervesence on the palate and a medium-full body.  Fairly tasty.  Indeed similar to an American Robust Porter style with added rye.

bottle from bbb63, pours a deep brown/black, head is a creamy layer that sticks to the sides of th glass.  aroma is hoppy and chocolatey, both in very soft amounts, hops having a slightly floral aspect. flavor has a distinct porter feel to it, very burnt coffee flavor, but is smoother and a fuller mouthfeel.  the hops and some sweet chocolates come in on the end, and the lingering taste is the floral hops i picked up at the beginning as well as maybe a bit of smokiness.  a very interesting and enjoyable beer.

12 oz bottle.  Brown-black hue with an off-white, rocky head.  Large visibile carbonizzles.  Roasty, chocolate, coffee malt.  Pine and floral hops.  Prune esters.  Very balanced.  Moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter flavor becomes a lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter finish.  Medium body, velvety texture, moderate carbonation.  The bottom line is: tastes like a roasty IPA, neat!
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 mmm... malty hoppiness... like an IPA fornicated with a porter or Stout.  This was cool. Not awesome but it was good.  :)  yummers  thanks for bringin this b
color is almost black, like tiger woods.  aroma is lots of rye bread and coffee.  Very dry and lots n lots of malts in the body.  catch some charcol aftertaste, word.

Deepest ruby brown possible with a thin head.  Very little rye aroma, but a strong hit of coffee.  Interesting flavor which was a little hard to peg down.  Malt?  Wheat?  Rye?  Definitely processed grains of some sort with some nuttiness.  Bitter finish.

When I first poured this beer, I smelled smoke.  "This isnt supposed to be a rauchbier..." I thought to myself -- and then I glanced out the window and saw my neighbors grilling brats which had probably been drowning a few minutes ago, boiled in MGD and onions.  But I digress...  Poured nearly pitch black with a nice medium sized chocolate ice cream-colored head.  There were a few floaties in it -- Im not sure where they came from -- but other than that the beer looked very appetizing.  The aroma was big on bittersweet chocolate, coffee (so I guess Id call it "mocha") and resinous hops.  A little sour and vinous smelling -- maybe the rye?  Flavors are strong, chocolately, with roasty sweetness up front and coffee and sourish, sticky hops in back.  A little fizzy.  I certainly did not give this beer the highest marks, but it definitely is good -- Ive enjoyed the three bottles that Ive had so far.  I will buy another 6er of this next winter, as it is a pleasant, interesting beer made for drinking.
Poured Black with a huge light tan foamy head.Nose of hops and what I think is rye. Taste is stout with hps and again, I think rye. The hop is sticky, this is unige and enjoyable.

05.17.05  12oz bottle thanks to Facto.  Nearly black pour with lofty tan head.  Aroma is fresh and grassy, yet roasty.  Lots of rye, and I dont always smell or taste rye unless its prominent.  Really tasty, great balance of roasty, buttery malt smoothness, and a certain rye prominence.  An emergence of something tasting like sunflower seeds.  Palate never gets too dry or too bitter, Im starting to find that alot of these rye beers have an excellent soft mouthfeel.  Thanks Matt!

Thanks to wohlfs for this beer.

Poured black with a fizzy light tan head.  Nicely balanced aroma of strong hops and roasted coffee.  Taste pretty much follows from the aroma, though doesnt seem quite as craftfully balanced.  Great hop flavor laced with bitter roasted chocolate, with the bitter chocolate dominating in the finish.  Leaves a taste similar to Rogue Shakespeare Stout.  Tasty and unique, but not as palatable on its own.

Pours a black thats brown around the edges. The tan head is a good size and looks like rolling hills as seen from above. The aroma is quite roasty, a bit of coffee and chocolate and a hint of rye bread underneath that. The flavor is also very much like a dry stout with a sticky bit of fresh citrus hops running along the top of the flavor. Excellent.

12oz. bottle thanks to TAR. Dark brown, almost black with a small tan head. Aroma of chocolate malt, coffee and hops. Nice dry roasted malt flavor with some dark chocolate and a fine hop bitterness. Very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Pours a deep & cloudy dark brown with no head.  Nose is complex ...lotsa roasted maltiness with choco-coffee notes, definitely some vanilla detected, definitely a burnt quality.   Flavor is big....lotsa  coffee, toffee malts, blend well with a nice hop bitterness that is more pervasive as I drink.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, nice dry bitter finish.
The hops did suprise me in this.  Wasnt what I was expecting, based on the pitch black appearance and chocolate aroma.  This was very good; dry finish, yet smooth and creamy as well.

Deep brown with red streaks and a thick, frothy tan head.  Cool, hoppy aroma of pine and light grapefruit, burnt malt, chocolate, caramel, rye bread and a bit of licorice.  The body is thick, full and creamy.  The carbonation is subtle, but sufficient for the beer and the rye adds a smooth texture to the body.  The flavor is quite a shock at first.  The aroma lends itself to a hoppy bitterness, but the roasted bitterness up front takes one by surprise.  Once recovering, a moderate sweetness comes across the tongue.  Despite this, the layered bitterness of the hops join the roasted malt to make it really interesting.  Things keep confusing the senses, but each change is pleasant and welcome.  A tasty beer that is quite different and totally good.

Hops, rye,  and roasted coffee aroma.  Dark brown.   Rich coffee and the rye in the is very good.  Not overpowering but gives a good taste alond with the rest of the flavors.  Medium in the body and the aftertaste is malty.

Dark brown, puffy and creamy tan head. You can tell by the aroma it is dry hopped... full of burnt citrusy hops that accompany roasted caramel, stale bread, and coffee. Surprising amount of hops in flavor too... more citrusy / grapefruit rind, roasted sweet coffee malts. Indeed, quite like nutty rye bread in the finish.  Well balanced and delicious. Seems simple, yet well put together. Founders makes brewing seem easy.

Very dark brown and a little hazy with no head. Complex aroma of roasted malt with chocolate, coffee, vanilla, licorice, dark caramel, maybe a little bourbon and tar. Big body with a clean but lingering spicy, fruity, hoppy and dry finish. Flavor of cocoa, anise, coffee, toffee, a little mint, and hops. Exceptionally well balanced and well made ale.

12 oz bottle.  Deep clear black with ruby brilliance under the light and a lasting taupe head...big acidic carroway and sour breadiness in the aroma...rye present, dominant even on the tongue, just a tiny bit of sweetness to compliment the strong sour dryness, bit of port wine late...at first taste its reminiscent of a schwarzbier, but for the vinous quality and sourness.  I feel that I havent gotten it all, but alas I need another bottle..

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2007 Black with a light brown head that fades fast. Noticed some floaties as well.  Aroma is sweet, toasty, chocolate, and caramel. The toasted chocolate notes were rather savory. Very malty body with the hops coming through in the finish. Flavor is chocolate, toasted bread, nuttiness, a hint of vanilla, and floral/grassy hops. Creamy texture that coats the mouth and leaves a film. The finish was SLIGHTLY dry. Left lacing all the way down the glass.

Dark brown body, short-lived head.  Interesting aroma, with the tartness of the citric hops mingling with chocolate and coffee.  Good lush mouthfeel.  Unique flavors.  Nutty, slightly chocolatey, some stale coffee, good bitterness to balance the sweetness.  Interesting grainy aftertaste, I suppose from the rye?  Satisfying.

Bottle courtesy of Styles: Dark brown that appears black when in the glass; small tan head.  The aroma coming from this one is dominated by roasted malt & chocolate scents, with some coffee, spicy rye, penut shells, and a hint of citrus & grass.  Medium-full bodied and  softly carbonated.  It tastes quite bitter up front with notes of cocoa powder, roasted malt, and peppery rye.  Towards the middle I get a hint of caramel buried in there somewhere, as well as vanilla, and some citrus/grass hops that give off some light fruit notes if you hold it in your mouth for a bit.  Finishes dry with a bitter roasted nut flavor and tons of roasted malt & rye.  The mouthfeel and carbonation are excellent and the use of rye really adds some extra depth to the taste and smell.  I really enjoy this and reds rye from Founders.  Edit: If you let it breathe for a bit and warm to room temperature youll notice some nice fruity, sweet hop notes in the flavor & finish intermingling with the rye.
Poured clear dark brown with a beige head. Huge chocolate aroma. I had to smell this for a few minutes before drinking it. Light hops in the flavor dominated by chocolate. I dug it.

Poured dark brown but it turned black onece it was in the glass.  It had a small off-white head that mostly went away....just a little lacing.  Aroma is sharp, some coffee and rye.  Flavor is lightly sweet af frist with a heavy bitter finish that lasts.  I tasted chocolate, but the rye comes out the more you drink.  Creamy-full body with soft carbonation and a chalky, dry finish.

Ultra dark brown bordering black, khaki colored creamy head. Interesting twist of aromas here with notes of roasted coffee, rye, dusty cocoa, with dried citrus fruit backing it up. Well bittered up front followed to the end by toasted rye, vanilla bean, and more  powdery cocoa.  Medium bodied, zesty carbonation, dry roasty finish.  Very nice.   Thanks for the bottle Hopscotch via Growler.
Black Rye is the real deal. If you like dark, you will like this period.  A little bitter coming on, but if you like dark, then you like bitter.

Roasty, coffee, rye nose.  Puffy, lasting tan head.  Dark brown/black body, with hints of dark ruby amber.  Pleasantly bitter and biting, roasted malts, burnt toast, hint of dark caramel, dark nuts, cocoa, somewhat thin in body, but very pleasant and inviting mouthfeel.  Finishes with a prolonged bitterness, which fades away very cleanly.  Coffee, rye, hops.  Very drinkable, and quite delicious.

Pours dark brown and settles black with small tan head that dissapears quickly Aroma is full of big coffee flavor and a light hop.  Mild chocolate aroma.  Nice aroma balance.  Chocolate and roasted malts and a clean sharpness.  Bitterness  is present and matches nicely with toasted nutty finish.
Pours black with a fizzy off-white head.  Aroma is a mix of molasses and mild coffee.  Flavor is acetic with a little sweet finish.  Theres a slight coffee after-taste but nothing too strong.

bottle...dark semi-transparent pour with a nice tan head that lingers a while.  Roasted malt aroma, peaty and earthy as well.  Roasty malt flavor to start, a hint of hop bitterness in the middle, and a wonderful choco-roasty-malt finish.  The rye lends a beautiful bitterness in the finish also.  This is another incredible beer from the folks at Founders.  The sweetness just before the roasty bitter finish is impeccable.  The last two brews I have drank (Reds Rye and this Black Rye) are absolutely tremendous.

The Lure:Roasted malt serves as pine tree bark. Citrusy hops grow wild up the trunk for an impressive perfume of appealing equilibrium.

The Festivities:Delicate but firm roasted malt bitterness in a quaffable body appears harsh at times. Green, woody hops participate joyfully and impart dryness to this bold and flavorful quencher.

Transcendence:Who said a beer needed to be soft to be easy-drinking?

Pours a dark brown color with brown highlights and a ring of light brown lace. Great aroma and flavor of resinous hops, roasted malt and rye, mild bitter finish. Light to medium body, dry texture, soft carbonation. Another excellent, well made beer from Founders.

Dark brown body, not opaque, light off-white ring. Very hoppy aroma, pine and pinneapple all over the place. Bready rye procures an appealing woodiness. Mellow grapefruit undertones. Well balanced palate thanks to the absence of acidity fmo those big hops. Expressive rye, well-hidden alcohol leads to a treachorously easy to drink beer. Light roastiness kicks in and overcomes the hops, so its hardly piney nor grapefruity in the finish. I enjoyed that. Smooth and mellow creamy texture brings coke memories with its big biting bubbles. Now if Founders managed to get the same head on their other beers than the one that thrones its imperial stout...

Pours the color of a strong double bock. Carbonated but no head. Mild hop toastyness in nose. Dryish watered down coffee and nut flavor with a slightly bitter finish. Not bad but wouldnt buy again. I like the red rye better.

Pours a watery opaque black with a fluffy tan head...Hop aroma dominates the nose along with some subtle chocolate undertones.  Surprisingly the hops are not very strong in the flavor and are taken over by the dark rye malt leaving a nice chocolate and roasted coffee flavor...a bit disappointed with the "big hop flavor" missing in my bottle...I just dont taste them.  Finish is a bit dry and nutty...rating would increase with a better hop profile.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 This pours black and with a brown halo rather than a head.  The aroma is dark and roasted with some hot spices and a smattering of hop bitterness.  The rye is very peppery and spicy on the tongue, and this feeling lingers.  Deep, rich rasted malts and grains, some hints of coffee, and a bitter, dry finish.  Both interesting and tasty.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Definitely not what I expected.  Dark pour with noticeable hops and some roasty malts in the nose.  Rich flavor with chocoalte, roasted beans and some hop presence.  Smells like an APA, drinks like a stout.  Go figure.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2005 Its surprising how distinct the rye flavor is in this one. Aroma is similar to a roasty porter, but the distinction comes in the flavor and aftertaste. Up front there is a dry roasted grain flavor with notes of hops and chocolate. In the end there is a deep rye flavor that complements very well. A little more body would help IMO, but this makes you want to continuosly drink as the dryness of the rye overtakes you. This is one of the few dry beers that I like.

Pours black with a tan head that fades. Aroma is of dark fruit, roast, rye bread, chocolate, and a slight dry noble hops. Flavor is rich and complex. Chocolate, roast, dark rye bread, mild grassy/flowery/herbel hops. Nice balance and interplay between the sweet chocolate, the dry rye, and the bitter hops. Robust but so very drinkable. One of those beers I just cant put down.

Bottle... Very dark, hazy, ruby ale with a small, creamy, well-tanned head. Great retention. Lots of chocolate and vanilla in the aroma with a hint of brown sugar. Well-balanced, unsweetened cocoa flavor with some light notes of mocha. Light to medium-bodied and watery with lively carbonation. Crisp, grassy finish. Leaves a very silky coating on the tongue. Interesting and very good. Thanks go out to growler for the bottle!
Really nice brew! Deep copper colored pour raising a thick white head. Hoppy,malty with a little hint of sourness. Very easy drinker.

Thanks to BBB63 for this one.  Pours dark brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma of malt, big hops, some chocoff, rye.  Tastes malty, hoppy, with a roasty, toasty malt finish along with some chocoff and spice.  A porter at heart, with a solid hop presence for good measure.  Unique and delicious.

Dark brown-ruby body, almost opaque. The head is big, creamy, and tan.Weeping sheets of lace. The aroma is roasted malt, rye, coffee, and piney hops. The flavor is chocolate, coffee, rye, burnt malts, bitter throughout, piney hops, and even some smokiness. The body is medium, a tad fizzy, and quite bitter. An interesting brew to be sure.

pours a dark brown, almost black color.  aroma is roasted chocolate, and a nice hop note.  flavor is much like the aroma, with the added note of tabacco.  good smooth body.  this is not bad, but the red rye id better i think.

Bottle: Pours to a deep brown hue with a small but creamy head and excellent lace. Shocking piney and grapefruit notes on the nose with mocha and smoky malts, coffee, dusty esters, and a touch of green tea also detected. The taste was the equal of the aroma with the hops at the forefront and a solid malty and chocolatey background. Coffee, smoke and hazelnut notes also appear. The palate is a tad thin but does have some creamy character. Overall, this is like a hopped up porter and quite refreshing and enjoyable. Mikey likey!
Tap. Black color with medium tan head. Very complex aroma and flavor. Enjoyable to drink and good combination of flavor and finish. The tap room at Founders is good place to locat.

A wonderful jet black ale, with some brown highights make this beer very differnt.  The soff-white colored head on top of the very dark liquid is quite attractive. The aroma of coffee &  chocolate hit the nose as well This is a very full body stout and not for the week. The balance of hops to malt with just a touch of rey make it top notch.

Bottle, from Julios. Ok nose, Sweet and roasty. Kinda earthy peaty, hints of chocolate and/or carmel too. Clean orangy dark brown color. Good head that faded to nothin. Malt flavor, Smoke, burnt, baking chocolate, peat thing. Thinner body, lite creamy mouthfeel, dry smokey finish. Nice beer, easy drinking. Another winner from Founders
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle:  Aromas of dark chocolate, roasted malt, and rye.  Pours dark brown, virtually black, with a small light tan hed with decent retention.  Great lacing.  Flavor is suprisingly bland after expectations based on the aroma.  There isnt much up front.  Light rye in the middle.  Chocolate is very light and it comes in the finish with a little coffee.  Moderate hops in the finish.   Light black coffee aftertaste.   Flavors intensify as it warms and it begins to improve.

pours a nice dark color w/ a fairly small tan head and a nice coffee light malt aroma and a touch of light hops...palate is nicely carbonated a little thin but solid. the flavor is lightly hoppy but underneath a burnt coffee malt flavor... its pretty dang good, with a nice warm finish.

Bottle.  The Red seemed much more impressive.  This seems to be  a touch more subdued in malt and hop use.  Pours out a deep black color with chestnut hues when backlit.  Fast fading brown head leaves no lacing.  Aroma is of deeply roasted malts.  Some coffee and some nutty aromas.  Fairly crisp.  Hops dont linger as long as the red.  Still a decent beer however!!

Pours a light tan, two finger head, fades slowly and leaves a ton of lace. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Color is deep red almost black. Nose is coffee. Starts and finishes with a burnt coffee flavor, the hops are always there with a slight hoppy after taste.  Good winter beer.  $1.80 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.

Now were talking.  Hoppy and roasted aroma all the way to the bank...if that makes sense.  There is of course the stout appearance on this brew. The flavor holds true to the aroma of creamy malt roasted action, light rye flavor and a good balanced bitterness to fill it out.  I must say, Founders is gaining some serious credibility of top-of-the-middle tier beers.

Deep black color, full cocoa/tan head..nice lookin...I like it okay...
Aroma: rich and creamy, big, grainy, feeling, almost loud... very dark.
Taste: rich and full, very dark and tasty, posssessing exceptional grit, very full texture, hearty mouthfeel.
Medium bodied, so-so finish...kind of curious about the need for a beer of this kind, it doesnt satisfy like a porter or a stout. A nice drink, though not much to really remember.
Hurrah, Black Rye, ...

Pours a pitch black, small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt,  coffee and chocolate. Flavor is similar, with a hop with roasted malt flavorl, rye overtones with choclate, and a "grassy" overall feel. Very smooth palate, very impressive. Thanks Dave, I owe ya onel!

Has an essentially black body with a so-so off-white head.  The aroma is based on chocolate with a nice combination of rye and grass-stem hops layered on top.  Wonderful flavor!  Has a dry chocolate backbone with grassy, pineapple hops perfectly bridged by spicy rye.  Dry finish with an emphasis on coffee beans and the hops.  The carbonation is about right, the body might be a little thin.

Dark brown color with a taller dense tan head. Rye and roasted malt mixed with mild pine, licorice and hint of citrus. Fairly thin and a touch too much fizzy, this does seem to thicken as it warms. Loads of coffee, dark rye and roasted malt with a mild citric finish. Absolutely huge linger of malt with some rye,  touches of dry caramel and roasted malts. This is a real black ale, that demands attention.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2005 now that ive had a sixer of it, i want to update my rating: dark, roasted, minty, bready, chocolately, and coffeely. more like a porter influenced american strong slash ipa. or a minty alpha king, but instead of the caramel replace it with chocolate and rye. this is gooooood.  uprated palate.

Pours black with a decent baige head. Aroma is mostly hops with some spice from the rye. Flavor was roasted malts and coffee with a little hops. Was like a light porter in a way, which is a little turn-off for me. But overall a decent brew. These guys might give Bells a run in the future.

Dark and chocolate in color with a very light head that doesnt stick around long.  As I opened the bottle and took a whiff, the very strong smell of chocolate hops burst out of the bottle.  roasted marshmellow malty flavor with a very clean and crisp finish.  Another good one from Founders

JCW dropped this baby on me! Thanks John!

A black brew fills my glass with a mediocre beige head that kicks shortly. Lovely hop nose! Pine and light cotrus notes, spicey with faint chocolatey fumes too boot. A medium bodied brew, lightly oily. Hops up front on the palate mingled with notes of roast, chocolate, coffee and the rye spiceyness but also more citrus notes as well. Neat combo! Very tasty indeed. Dry, spicey lightly roasty finish. Founders hops,em up huh!? Thanks again John!
Poured a black with big tan head.Sweet chocolate malt aroma. Nice chocolate malt flavor with also some caramel and hop flavor.

This is a most enjoyable treat!  The hops greet you as you pop the cap, some spicy pine greets the nose.  I was too busy pouring to invigorate the pour.  Deep ruby in color.  Lighter than a porter in body, but that is expected in this ale.  Flavor bounces around from burnt chocolate, to caramel coated nuts, to a nice zingy hoppy surprise.  The rye greets you at the finish with a fine how do you do.  This is a very nice beer!  Many thanks to Silphium for the sample, thanks Brad!

Dark mahogany in color with a slight off white to tan head.   The aroma was that of roasted coffee and grapefruit hops, very interesting.  The taste had that roasted coffee taste with grapefruity hops, carmel and maybe a hint of chocoalte, again very interesting.  This was quite drinkable and I would enjoy having it again.
bitter chocolate, syrupy rye body.  Black in color, interesting, very nice.

from the bottle. poured a reddish brown, with a light tan head. aroma bitter chocolate, toffee, yeast, hops. flavor, toffee. bitter sweet chocolate, hints of caramel, a nice bitterness, some hops and malts and this one after the breakfast stout, so this one was a little weaker in the flavors but still a very good beer.

Bottle pours near black, hues of coffee, large frothy tannish head, with attractive lacing. &nbsp Enjoyable combination of hops, toasted malts, and chocolate malts on the nose. &nbsp Smooth chocolatey maltiness up front, followed by a bit more hop bitterness. &nbsp Notes of coffee and hints of butter. &nbsp Mmmm... very tasty! &nbsp Beaut of a body, with a slightly thick & syrupy mouthfeel. &nbsp FInishes a bit oily, lingering chocolate malts and a soft bitterness. &nbsp Very tasty indeed! &nbsp Thanks goes out to TAR for the trade!

Bottle. I received this in one of those holiday 12 packs.  Ive wanted to sample this for some time and was glad to see it there.  Dark, opaque red /brown with a beige head.  Nice lacing.  Toasty aromas, malty sweetness.  Great mouthfeel, flavors of chocolate and bitter rye.  Like drinking some russian rye bread.  It was quite good.

On tap:  Roasty, aroma after I let it warm up for a while.  The rye provides a good backbone for the complexities to unfold on the palate.  I liked it better than some of the other rye beers they have now and in the past.  A little more substantial, as far as feeling on the palate and complexity.

2004 bottle.  Wonderful deep burgundy-violet hued brown ale, with some darker, almost black tinges and a small off-white, old piano key colored head.  Aroma of sweet milk chocolate, light roasted notes, pieces of hops hit the nose as well.  Some dry, herbal/anise-like notes on the end.  Flavor begins, quite unexpectedly, with a dose of very sweet toffee and light rye notes.  The beer progresses through a thick bodied godiva liqueur-like flavor with toasted malts providing some nutty nuances.  Syrupy (almost) caramel and roasted grains round out the finish, with some very bitter citric hops.  Kind of tastes like one of those chocolate oranges that you smack and then they break apart.  Just an all out unique and flavorful beer which gladly follows no real style guidelines.  After finding the red rye very boring, this was a marvelous surprise.  WIll be buying more of it.
Well, you guessed it, this is black.  Big toffee aroma.  Bready and sweet, with a pumpernickel pounce, with an strong bitter end.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 Dark crimson. Ivory head leaves clingy rings of milky consistency on the glass. Piney hops and Chocolate malt dominate the aroma. Soft notes of sugared grapefruit, dry dark chocolate, ink, and anise. Creamy carbonation. Semi-oily. Opens exuberantly hoppy with a stingily bitter backbone of sugared grapefruit drenched with heaps of palate-coating Chocolate malt. Citric hops heighten at the center as discreet roast acidity penetrates the velvety chocolate profusion. Dry, bittersweet espresso accompanies a ravishing blend of  spruce-dipped chocolate and mandarin orange in the finish as resinous hop oils impart their lasting fullness on the palate with prolonging grapefruit-tinged belches soon following. The best of both worlds.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark brown, almost black, thick tan head that settled down. Bitter chocolate, roasty rye, coffee.  Creamy and crisp at the same time on the palate. Dry grainy finish.

Deep brown, almost black, body with a frothy tan head.  There was sweetness in the nose, rye, toffee.  Good full body and a smooth feel.  Flavor is hints of toffee and chocolate and coffee.  I really didnt get much rye in the nose or the taste.  Still, a good drink.
deep dark brown with a big fluffy head.  piney hoppy spicy aroma--nice roasty body, has lots of rye/fennel flavors with a large hops presence.  maybe too hoppy, but pretty good.

Pours dark brown almost black.  Nose is quite stingy, sprucy.  Flavor is roasted malt, smooth and slick with underlying bitterness.  Nice hop balance in the middle. Subtle rye flavor.  Begs for another sip.  Smooth roasted hop finish.

Pours with a coffee opaqueness and a thick light tan head.  Aroma is deep, dark and roasty with some mustiness and fresh hops hiding somewhere within.  Starts with a dry roasty mocha sweetness revealing a touch of rye toward a gritty and well-hopped finish.  Nicely balanced throughout, this is a unique and flavorful brew.  Thanks secret santa!

Black beer with a white head.  Soft aroma that has nuances of both dark malts and yeast.  Very soft flavor, lacking the burnt, dry astringent flavors I expected when I first poured it.  There was a little touch of nuttiness and coffee.  Very smooth.  Almost like a Schwartzbier.  Dry finish with pleasant hoppy flavor.
color is opaque black, head is creamy tan, aroma is heavily roasted with a nice hoppy presence. flavor is dominated by roast and a decent bitterness in the finish.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2005 Pours a alomst black when held up to light.  Aroma is somewhat hoppy with a mix of malt.  Flavor is a strong chocolat/coffee combo.  The flavor is a bit overpoweing at first but im liking it the more i drink it.  More a stout than a ale but still its a very flavorful brew.

Piney nose is the fisrt thing I notice from this dark brick red pint. Head is frothy and "burnt sienna".  As it warms the nose lets  the rye and chocolate have their moment of fame. Body is thick and malty, nutty, rich. Another big beer from this pub.  Malty middle is chocolatey and slightly peaty. Hoppy piness in the finish, bitter, porter-like. Damn, I keep drinking reaaly great beers here, I may never leave. The popcorn is my dinner.

Ruby, almost black.  Off yellow head.  Very rye/soy aroma.  Hops help to keep it from being overpowering.  Really pungent smoke.  A bit of lemon.  Strongly bitter.  Too much for me.  Thanks to drew for the bottle

A unique beer, kind of like an American brown ale, but up the dark malts into porter range, and add a bunch of rye.  Hoppy aroma, piney and citrusy, with plenty of underlying malt and hints of coffee.  Very dark brown in color, tan head.  Flavor is an interesting blend of American hops and dark roasted grains, think porter hopped like an American IPA.  There is something else going on in the flavor that I cant identify, so Im going to assume that is the rye.  Medium body, slight astingency, but still easy drinking.
PNW hops peak through a chocolatey aroma, mostly black with a dark ruby tint and a khaki colored head, pronounced rye throughout mixes well with good hop flavor and slight chocolate finish
Deep black with vigorous tan head. Some pine hops aromas. Flavors are roast malt and pine hops with some hints of rye (mostly in the aftertaste).

Dark reddish brown almost black color with decent creamy head that leaves lacing in my glass. Chocolate and pine aromas, chocolate, oatmeal and rye bread flavors. Medium bodied with a creamy, smooth mouthfeel, finishes clean. Very tasty and drinkable almost reminds me of an oatmeal stout.

I realy liked this one.  Black as a stout, pours with a moderate brown head.  Aroma is mostly piney hops with some roasted flavors that follow it up.  Thin bodied.  Flavor is mostly rye, with the finish from beginning to end all hops.  Moderate bitterness.  This beer is somewhat reminensist to me of Alpha Klaus 2002.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005 Cold chocolate coffee - yum!   Super dark brown/black body, short long lasting head, ok lacing.  Aroma is roasty hopped rye bread.  Nice rye bite in the middle and end of the taste.  Body is somewhat thin - keeps you drinking more.  Another winner from Founders.  And ya gotta love the AC/DC styled font on the label!

Color of a classic porter (brownish/black with deep, ruby highlights).  Head is tan.  Solid, black malt roast, cream, just-picked, spicy, floral hops, and perfumey rye aroma.  Flavor is much the same (good) with black malt dryness dominating at mid-palate then hop flavor and rye malt in the long finish.  The flaked rye creates a slightly gelatinous mouthfeel that is complemented by the hop flavor but is sharply contrasted and dried out by the black malt.  A little more hop acidity would clean this up even more.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2004 mmmmmmmm...beeeerrrrrrrrrr
i was surprised by how flavorful this beer was...spicy, hoppy, and citrus-like flavor complementing its dark roasted taste.  Very pleased!
We have a winner. Great rye bite, slight sourness, and piney hops on top of smoky malting. Body a tad thin. Flavorful. Not subtle by any stretch!

text: On tap at Founders and also newly bottled (the first new bottled Founders beer in some time).  This is a rather aggressively hopped dark rye beer; the crisp, spicy, piney hops complement the tingly, spicy, and somewhat fruity rye malt.  The flavor profile is quite dense and almost takes on a roasted character.  I think this will be popular once its distributed.
